dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An unfinished section of tunnel carved through bare earth braced with pit-props and shored with timber. Rubble and wood and construction equipment are scattered around. Dim work-lights are strung along the roof, but barely illuminate the scene. An emergency generator CLATTERS awa somewhere in the b.g. At the junction of a dark side-tunnel, two Organisation T guards -- a SERGEANT and a CORPORAL -- are working furiou HAMMERING huge lengths of timber across the mouth of the tunnel, gradually sealing it off. Their noses and mouths are masked against the dust by gri cotton scarves, but their unease is plain to see. As they continue working, an 0.T. PRIVATE emerges from th gloom of the main tunnel, jogging towards them. He slows a halt as he joins his two comrades, and begins to quickl fill them in.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE
dialogues.text: That’s the last of them. Everybody else is out. The Sergeant glances around at the Private, but doesn’t s working.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Put a face mask on, you idiot! But the young Private seems impatient and cavalier. He ignores the comment and simply wipes the sweat from his n gesturing curiously at the side-tunnel:

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE
dialogues.text: Look, when do we find out the big secret? What's the panic? What're we supposed to be afraid of? The other two exchange a glance.

dialogues.speaker: CORPORAL
dialogues.text: Never you mind! Just give us a hand to finish up. Quick! The Private joins in reluctantly, and they hoist another thick plank into place, holding it in position while the Corporal HAMMERS a nail through one end.  2. A CREAK -- and dust begins to spill from the roof. The Corporal carries on regardless, NAILING the other end. But the Private is still inquisitive.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE
dialogues.text: Nobody out there’s got a clue what’s going on. wWhy’re we doing this?

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Because we've been ordered to! Isn't that enough for you? Another plank is lifted into place, and the barricade is nearing completion... then the distant CLATTER of the generator falters. The lights dim -- then brighten again as the generator returns to its previous steady rhythm. The two NCO's FREEZE -- holding their breath -- looking a each other with speechless expectation. The generator SPLUTTERS again -- terminally, this time. They let go of the plank, and it CRASHES to the floor. Scrabbling for their torches, starting to panic. The Priv watching bemused as the other two CURSE under their breat The Generator NOISE is now on a rapid downward curve, slo and dying. The lights are going with it... ... and a solid, shocking blackness drops on them with su SILENCE. Their torches are on but the beams are feeble, struggling penetrate the darkness. The Sergeant can't help himself: SERGEANT (cont'd) Oh, Christ! His voice ECHOES away into the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE
dialogues.text: The generator’s just out of petrol. What's so --

dialogues.speaker: CORPORAL
dialogues.text: Shhh! A pause ... then, from the side-tunnel, comes a new noise: A fain SCUFFLING sound.  3. They automatically shine their torches at the barricade their fear tangible now -- affecting even the young Priva whose cocky expression of disdain is rapidly dropping fro his face. The Sergeant’s voice is tight:

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: It's happening! Just like they said!

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE
dialogues.text: What is it? Is someone in there? But the other two are already backing away along the tunn in horrified disbelief. The Private begins to follow after them, his nervousness growing by the second... the SCUFFLING getting LOUDER... PRIVATE (cont’d) For God's sake, what is it? What's in there? But the other two turn and RUN.

dialogues.speaker: LOUDER STILL...
dialogues.text: And as his composure finally crumbles and he RUNS after t the Private looks BACK over his shoulder one last time -- face now betraying an expression of sheer terror...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Densely packed pine trees in all directions. Snowflakes flutter down silently from a steel-grey sky. A German Army supply lorry crawls along a dirt road which winds through the forest, engine racing and wheels spinni as it slithers through the river of mud churned up by a hundred tanks and vehicles long gone. Accompanying it are a score of infantry, breath pluming i the frosty air. Some trudge alongside the lorry, offering shoulder occasionally to straighten it as it fishtails through the slush. The remainder follow twenty yards behi Each is sagging under the weight of helmet, equipment and sodden greatcoat. Their uniforms mark them as regular army -- but their coa carry the black and silver cuff-bands of an ‘elite’ divis  4. ENGELS, heading up the group of stragglers, reaches into bread-bag and pulls out a half-eaten bar of chocolate. He pops a piece into his mouth, and chomps it wearily. Following in his wake are EBERT, SCHENKE, KREUZMANN, BAUM HEYDRICH, unit medic FRANKE, and C.0., LT. KRUPP. We’1ll to know each of them soon enough. Two or three others mak up the numbers -- but our group of eight are the main pla for now.

dialogues.speaker: ENGELS
dialogues.text: They’11 be heading on to Brussels without us, at this rate. Ebert, moving with a lithe, cat-like alertness despite hi tiredness, throws Engels an idle sideways glance.

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: What’s your hurry?

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: (a snort, butting in) Well, it’s not to win any medals that’s for sure. Engels ignores Schenke’s comment, and responds to Ebert’s question.

dialogues.speaker: ENGELS
dialogues.text: What’s the hurry? Have a guess.

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: (bored) The women.

dialogues.speaker: ENGELS
dialogues.text: God, no! They’re like French women - coarse hair and wide-pored skin. Next guess. Heydrich -- older than the rest, a veteran -- chips in.

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: Surely not the booze?

dialogues.speaker: ENGELS
dialogues.text: (shaking head) Nah! Cat’s piss, all of it. (to them all) Any more? Engels looks around -- but nobody else is interested exce Kreuzmann, who is looking to him eagerly for the answer Engels glances around once more, then sighs in defeat.  ENGELS (cont’d) Only two good things ever came out of Belgium: one’s the road to Germany, and the other... Engels snaps off a chunk of chocolate, and tosses it back Kreuzmann with a wink and a warm smile. Kreuzmann quickly tears off the remaining wrapper with nervy fingers.

dialogues.speaker: KREUZMANN
dialogues.text: Chocolate! Engels cocks his head appreciatively.

dialogues.speaker: ENGELS
dialogues.text: Got it. You can say what you like, but they make damned good -- A bullet SMACKS into Engels’ throat, blowing a chunk out his neck as it exits. The distant RIFLE SHOT follows a second behind. Almost simultaneously, a demolition charge EXPLODES under lorry ahead, taking the legs off the accompanying troops. The front end of the vehicle HEAVES into the air and CRAS back down in a smoking ruin. The group SCATTER as a hail of SNIPER FIRE rains down: Heydrich catches a bullet in the leg, and he and Ebert he forward and left off the road; Baumann takes a gully seve yard back, also to the left; Schenke, Kreuzmann, Krupp an Franke dive right. The rest take cover as best they can. Engels, paralysed, drops to his knees in the mud. Hands a his throat stemming the stream of blood. Jaw working to speak, but only producing GURGLES. He’s HIT again, in the shoulder, but still remains upright.

dialogues.speaker: KREUZMANN
dialogues.text: (a scream) Get him out of there! But all attention is focussed forward as the rest of the swing into action in unison, settling behind cover to ret FIRE with well-practised precision. With bullets SPITTING down all around, it’s all they can do to stay put. . while their legless, dying comrades SCREAM in the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: snuggle into cover across the road, Heydrich dragging his injured leg painfully. Shock and confusion showing on their pale faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How bad’s the leg? Heydrich simply shakes his head, more concerned about Eng who’s still propped up on his knees in the kill-zone.

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: We need to give Engels some covering fire - see if someone can get to him.

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: Angle’s wrong from here. Sniper- fire’s coming from up left somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: What about retreating to that gully back there ...? Someone BURSTS through the bushes suddenly behind them -- their guns are half turned in response before they realis it’s Baumann.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: We’ve got to move! They’re coming up from behind. Ebert looks around, alert.

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: I don’t see any --

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: I tell you they’re coming. It’s a trap! Heydrich and Ebert cast a concerned glance over at their stricken comrade -- then Ebert makes a hasty decision.

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: Alright. Let’s find cover forward. They jump to it and move forward through the trees, rifle pointed in readiness, Heydrich limping along as best he c But they’ve barely gone ten yards before a MACHINE GUN op up from somewhere front right, bullets CHOPPING into the trunks all around them -- forcing them back EBERT (cont’d) Shit! ! Baumann and Ebert run for cover -- but Heydrich trips... As bullets KICK into the snow around him, Heydrich SHOUTS help involuntarily...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slumped in the kill-zone, Engels is on automatic pilot. Despite his appalling injuries his free hand struggles to open the flap on his holster, to get to his P.38. He just manages it when two more bullets CHOP into him, smashing into arm and abdomen. He slumps back on his haunches with a gurgled MOAN -- but miraculously, still stays upright.

dialogues.speaker: KREUZMANN, SCHENKE, KRUPP AND FRANKE
dialogues.text: huddle deeper behind cover as a sustained FUSILLADE of sh rains down upon them suddenly.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: Christ!! Kreuzmann is making no attempt to return fire, simply sta impotently at Engels, who has somehow summoned the streng to shuffle around towards them, vainly trying to inch his to cover. Franke, meanwhile -- his helmet bearing the red cross of field medic -- averts his eyes so as not to look upon the he cannot help. Lieutenant Krupp is looking around for options.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: We’re dead if we stay here! (a shout) Heydrich! Baumann!? No reply.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: Where are they? The sniper fire abates momentarily. But then something small, ovoid and black sails gracefully out of the trees towards them, SPLASHING heavily into the mud beside Engel SCHENKE (cont’d) (a shout) Grenade! ! Schenke, Krupp and Franke hit the dirt -- but Kreuzmann i frozen in horror, his eyes locked with those of Engels. The grenade EXPLODES with a sharp, shattering blast, taki Engels with it.  And Kreuzmann is caught in the shockwave...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. A forest clearing. It’s later. Darker. Dusk is falling with the snow. A few brief moments of perfect stillness i the picture-postcard scene, far away from the action. Not even the distant thud of gunfire any longer. Then Ebert, Heydrich and Baumann stumble through the tree Ebert scans the forest ahead with exhausted eyes, his rif held ready at his side -- his free arm supporting the accident-prone Heydrich. Heydrich’s leg, by now, is soake with crusted blood. His face is creased with pain, but st he keeps watch left and right, pistol in hand. Baumann brings up the rear. He’s edgy, scanning the trees behind them with rifle aimed. A few more steps, and Ebert pauses to catch his breath. H whispers, just loud enough for Baumann to hear.

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. Baumann crouches and waits, still covering the rear. Untangling himself from Heydrich, Ebert creeps forward an takes up position beside a tree several yards away, study the forest ahead through field-glasses. After a moment, he lowers the binoculars triumphantly. EBERT (cont’d) Bunker!

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. ANTI-TANK BUNKER ‘FRIEDA’ - DUSK CLOSE -- as the steel-shutter of a narrow observation loo hole SLIDES open suddenly. A glint of eyes in the darknes beyond. Three metres to the left, in a second loophole sunk into camouflaged concrete face of the bunker, the twin barrels a combined anti-tank cannon/machine gun swivel into actio taking aim. There is the heavy metallic CLICK-CLACK of a gun being cocked. A muffled voice SHOUTS from inside

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay where you are! and Ebert’s distant voice replies from off-screen:

dialogues.speaker: EBERT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Don’t shoot! Comrade! WIDER -- down a shallow snow-covered slope, on a frozen d road which dog-legs through rows of concrete tank-traps, three approaching soldiers stop dead in their tracks. Ebert waves his rifle wearily, a dirty white handkerchief tied to the barrel. He calls again, cautious: EBERT (cont’d) We’re coming in. Alright? No reply from the bunker. Ebert sets off again anyway, half-dragging Heydrich up th slope. Baumann follows a few paces to the rear, still watching the trees behind them. The barrels of the guns follow them from the bunker as th approach.

dialogues.speaker: SIDE AND REAR OF BUNKER
dialogues.text: The huge bunker is sunk into the tree-covered hillside. T three soldiers make their way up the slope and along the wall, stumbling occasionally in the snow, or on the hidde ropes of the camouflage netting. At the rear, a deep trench leads to the entrance: this is overlooked by another loophole in the wall of the Entranc Defence Room. As they struggle down the crude steps into trench, the steel shutter of this loophole GRATES open to watch them. Ebert arrives first at the heavy steel door, and kicks it EBERT (cont’d) Open up, dammit! For a moment the three of them wait in silence and stilln Ebert looking up at the lettering moulded into the concre above the door. It reads ‘FRIEDA’. Sound of bolts SLAMMING back, and the door swings open. Ebert stands aside to let Heydrich hobble through first

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heydrich is barely inside before he is PUSHED roughly aga the wall, a pistol at his throat.

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: Hey! What the...? And everybody FREEZES. Heydrich is staring back into the face of another German soldier -- a reserve Volksgrenadier. This is MIRUS, an ol man with crazy eyes and a crazy demeanour. An old, livid wound is visible on his forehead -- and he looks ill.

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: (to Heydrich) Who are you? He rips open Heydrich’s collar, checking his dog-tag. MIRUS (cont’d) Let me hear you speak.

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: Heydrich. 13th Panzergrenadiers.

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: Let him go, old man!

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: (to Baumann) You! Say something. Why are you here?

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: We were ambushed. Now take it easy!

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: Ambushed?

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: It’s a bit late to be asking questions, Private. Put the gun down. Mirus blinks, his eyes slowly losing their crazy gleam. HEYDRICH (cont'd) The gun! Mirus finally backs off. Everybody BREATHES again. Heydri rubs his throat, cursing silently.  11. As if his mind has suddenly changed gear, Mirus looks at other three soldiers as if seeing them for the first time He stokes his old head wound unconsciously.

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: I’m sorry... The others look at him warily, unsettled by his radical change in temperament. MIRUS (cont‘d) We were warned, you see. About enemy infiltration units.

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: If you weren’t sure about us you should never have opened the door. Ebert SLAMS and bolts the door behind them. (They’re in a short, T-shaped passage: To their right, a small flight of steps leads down to another steel door; t the left, the Gas Lock which leads deeper into the bunker Mirus shuffles sheepishly for a second, embarrassed at hi behaviour, then gestures for them to follow.

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: This way. Mirus leads them through the

dialogues.speaker: GAS LOCK
dialogues.text: MIRUS (cont’d) What happened to you, again? then turns right through the gas-proof doors into the

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: Ambush. Americans. Doors in each wall of the corridor lead to the Generator and the Crew Room. Straight ahead is the door to the Gun Room. Peering around it curiously is a 2nd Volksgrenadier This is NEUMANN; young, almost a boy. Mirus snaps at him:

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: Keep watching the front! Neumann disappears out of sight as Mirus leads the others right again, into the --  12.

dialogues.speaker: CREW ROOM
dialogues.text: Bunks. Lockers. Pin-ups. Military mottoes painted on the walls. Small stove. Emergency Escape. A Christmas tree -- with an ironic cardboard SWASTIKA on top instead of an angel. The three newcomers slump down onto the bunks near the st A bit of warmth and comfort. The relief spreads across th faces -- but this only accentuates their pain and exhaust Heydrich stretches out his injured leg.

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: Ahhh!! Shit! Meanwhile, Mirus hovers nervously, occasionally coughing.

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: How far away did all this happen? The ambush?

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: Three, four kilometres.

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: But the front-line is supposed to be thirty-odd kilometres away.

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: That’s what we thought. One by one, they light up cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: God knows what the Yanks were doing there. Probably don’t even know themselves. Baumann is studying Mirus’s reaction:

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: They might be coming this way. Mirus turns pale. He looks at the other two for confirmation.

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: Will they?

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: Maybe. They were behind us for a while, back there. All they have to do is follow our tracks in the snow.  13.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: (to Mirus) How many men do you have? Mirus nervously strokes the wound on his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: Just one. The three newcomers stiffen, alert. The relaxation drains from their faces, to be replaced once more by tension.

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: You mean that kid?

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: Everybody else was sent forward. They even took our supplies.

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: Christ!

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: Is it like this all along the line, now? Just Reserves?

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I think so. (defensive) There’s not supposed to be any fighting here!

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: Someone forgot to tell the Yanks.

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: (to Mirus) You’d better get onto Area Command. Mirus turns to leave, fretting. Ebert calls after him. EBERT (cont’d) What was it you said before, about infiltration units?

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: Americans in German uniform. Sometimes they --

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: We know what they are. What about them?

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: We were just told to be on the lookout for them.  14.

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: Well, don’t shoot at anyone until you know who it is. There may be others coming, from our unit. Mirus nods and exits. Ebert snorts derisively. EBERT (cont’d) I don’t believe it! Kids and sick crazy old men left in charge.

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: That’s what it’s come to, alright A moment of brooding silence. Heydrich gets out his first aid kit and sees to his leg. Ebert gets up and smells the coffee pot on the stove. Ersatz! He pulls a sour face, but pours a mug-full anyway passes it around. Baumann continues where they’d left off

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: So, if the Yanks attack again it’1l be up to us.

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: They won’t necessarily come after us. They might have other priorities. But he doesn’t sound as if he quite believes it. And it’s clear from their faces that nor do Heydrich and Baumann. Ebert stares for a moment into his coffee mug -- then rai it in a tired, ironic toast: EBERT (cont’d) Well. Happy Christmas! Sudden SHOUT from the Gun Room:

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Someone’s coming!

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EBERT’S POV - THROUGH BINOCULARS A small group of German soldiers flit cautiously between trees, at the bottom of the slope overlooked by the bunke Three, maybe four of them.

dialogues.speaker: EBERT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Ours, alright. What's left of them.  15.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Can I see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ebert is peering out through the loophole. He passes the binoculars to Baumann, then turns to Neumann at the gun.

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: NEUMANN
dialogues.text: Neumann, sir. Ebert looks around: (The room is dim -- lights out becaus the loophole cover is open) 4.7 cm cannon/machine gun; am boxes; door to the Ammunition Room; not much else. In the b.g., Mirus is on the wall-mounted field-telephone LIBBING terse, monosyllabic comments and replies. Heydrich is leaning expectantly in the doorway. Ebert turns back to Neumann and indicates the huge gun;

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: Are you alright with this? Neumann nods with a hint of defiance;

dialogues.speaker: NEUMANN
dialogues.text: I used to be on a Flak unit. Ebert is quiet for a moment, looking sadly at this over- confident kid who should be back at home with his family. He gestures at Mirus and continues;

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: Did he explain to you what's going on? What's his name?

dialogues.speaker: NEUMANN
dialogues.text: Mirus. Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: Alright. Keep the gun trained on the trees. Just in case. Neumann nods. EBERT (cont’d) This isn't like shooting at planes. If you have to fire, use short bursts.  16. Another dismissive, slightly annoyed nod, and Neumann put his eye back to the gunsight. Mirus hangs up the phone. He's even more agitated, now.

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: They just said to let them know of any developments. That's all!

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: (ironic) Great! Sound of indistinct SHOUTING from outside.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: They're out of the trees. Coming in.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH BINOCULARS
dialogues.text: The four soldiers are now dodging between the concrete ta traps, waving towards the bunker. One of them is being helped along by the others. BAUMANN (0.S.) (cont'd) Krupp; Schenke; Franke. Can't see who they're dragging. Is it Kreuzmann?

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: Call out to them. Baumann opens his mouth to shout through the loophole... GUNFIRE bursts from the distant trees. Baumann and Ebert instinctively duck, grabbing their rifl

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: Shit! ! Mirus scrambles back to the gun. Pushes Neumann out of th way. Takes over. Baumann works the bolt on his rifle. Aims through the loophole. FIRES towards the trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Panic! The four newcomers are yelling incoherently as they scram up the icy slope, under fire from an unseen enemy. SHOTS are coming from the trees. KICKING into the snow around them. PRANGING off the concrete tank-traps. They'r in the open -- sitting ducks! Franke is dragging the injured Kreuzmann. Krupp is pushin them along with one hand and FIRING blindly towards the t with the other. Schenke brings up the rear, laying down a covering fire as he backs up the slope. On their faces is the fear of God. Schenke is HIT. He shouts involuntarily and stumbles; but second later he is up again, still firing. A bullet CLANGS against the side of Franke's helmet. He shouts a string of incoherent CURSES. All this happens in the space of six seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baumann squeezes off another SHOT. Ebert SHOUTS at Mirus;

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: What the hell are you waiting for?

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: I can't see the enemy!

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: Just fire! The machine gun EXPLODES into action. The NOISE within th confined concrete space is incredible. Baumann FIRES again, finishing his clip. Pulls away from the loophole. Ebert takes his place instantly, firing. Neumann breaks open a new ammo belt for the gun. Heydrich finishes loading shells into a rifle magazine. Tosses it to Baumann. EBERT (cont’d) They're coming around the side! Baumann SLAMS the clip into his rifle.  18.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: I’m alright here. Go! Ebert pulls away from the loophole and Baumann smoothly t his place, FIRING immediately. Heydrich catches on straight away. Follows Ebert out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: MAIN CORRIDOR AND GAS LOCK
dialogues.text: Ebert races for the rear. Heydrich hobbles behind him.

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: I'll get the door. They pile into the Gas Lock. Ebert branches off right. Heydrich goes left, around the dog-leg to the main door.

dialogues.speaker: ENTRANCE DEFENCE ROOM
dialogues.text: A small, bare, cramped room. Loophole in the outer wall. Ebert is at the loophole in an instant. Checks outside. SHOUTS through to Heydrich:

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: Clear!

dialogues.speaker: ENTRANCE PASSAGE
dialogues.text: Heydrich pulls open the door just in time for the new arrivals to SPILL inside, almost falling over each other. He SLAMS the door shut behind them. They collapse against the wall and sink to the floor. For few moments they say nothing, catching their breath and gradually realising they're still alive. Franke leans back with his eyes closed, pale and tremblin and hugging his steel helmet to his chest. Lieutenant Krupp wipes his face with a handkerchief -- an looks uneasily around the cramped space, pulling open his collar. The MUFFLED SHOOTING continues in the b.g. Heydrich takes a look at Kreuzmann, who is semi-conscious obviously in the worst condition.

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: What happened to the others?  19. Schenke struggles back to his feet painfully.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: Take a wild guess!

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: (to Heydrich) Who else is here?

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: Ebert and Baumann. Schenke starts to CHUCKLE ironically, but it emerges as a breathless cough. He looks at his wounded side -- then suddenly KICKS the wall in a violent, cathartic release o tension.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The machine gun is still BOOMING. The air is thick with cordite smoke. Baumann is trying to shout over the noise. The gun stops momentarily.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: enough! Hold fire! Another short BURST, and the gun stops again. Empty shells RATTLE down the collection tube. Sudden, complete silence. Mirus is glued, rigid, to the gunsight of the machine gun Baumann cautiously peeks through the loophole. BAUMANN (cont’d) That might hold them for a while. Krupp enters and takes in the scene. He throws a glance a Baumann, then addresses Mirus.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: Are you in charge here? Mirus and Neumann straighten to attention.

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Krupp heads immediately for the loophole, and Baumann ste aside to give him access. He turns for the door, but Krup calls him back:

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: Baumann!  20. Baumann stops where he is and waits patiently, whilst Kru studies the scene outside. KRUPP (cont’d) (to Mirus) You've been on to Area Command?

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: That covering fire was bloody late. Who was on the gun? Mirus hesitates momentarily -- coughing.

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: I was, sir. Krupp turns away from the loophole and looks Mirus up and down, taking in his Volksgrenadier uniform, and noticing the first time how sick he appears.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: Jesus! You look worse than us. Mirus says nothing, waiting for his telling-off. Neumann too is expectant -- but Krupp leaves it hanging in the ai KRUPP (cont’d) What other covering fire is there, apart from this?

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: There's a machine gun nest across the pass, sir. -- But nobody to man it. Krupp nods to himself.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: Alright. I'll talk to Area Command again. In the meantime, if anything moves out there, shoot. Instantly! Mirus SNAPS his heels, relieved.

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: Yes, sir! He turns back to the gunsight -- whilst Neumann's face betrays a momentary disappointment and irritation that Mi is off the hook. Meanwhile, Krupp half-turns to Baumann.  21.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: How long ago did you get here?

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: Just a few minutes before you did. A pregnant pause. BAUMANN (cont’d) We looked for you. Krupp turns away again without reply. He looks around the smoky room and suddenly seems short o breath. Face close to the loophole for air, he tugs at hi collar claustrophobicaly, and barks an order.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: Someone turn on the vents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kreuzmann is helped onto one of the bunks by Franke and Schenke, Heydrich following behind with his kit. Having l go of Kreuzmann, Schenke slumps onto the next bunk, looki down again at his bleeding side. He’s still steamed.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: Bastards! Behind us all the shitting way. Don't they know when to quit?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: Let me see it. Franke tries to look at his wound, but Schenke shrugs him angrily, gesturing at Kreuzmann:

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: Just get on with pampering him! Heydrich is still settling Kreuzmann.

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: (calmly) He’s hurt, Schenke. And he lost his friend back there. Schenke isn’t impressed, but drops the subject. Franke ta over the tending of Kreuzmann, and Heydrich hobbles over bunk at the other side of the room. Schenke eases himself back against the wall, taking deep breaths to calm himself and control the pain -- an Iron C 2nd class glinting visibly on his tunic.  22. Then he rests momentarily, eying Heydrich.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: How many do you think, out there?

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: Who knows? Enough, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: I reckon two or three snipers and a machine gun each side of the road. Plus maybe a couple on demolition.

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: (shaking head) More than that.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: If we hadn’t split up, we could’ve fought it out.

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: (impatient) And got ourselves killed.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: It was ten or twelve men at most.

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: Yes, and God knows how many more coming up from behind.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: (surprised) What do you mean? You saw others?

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: I didn’t see them, no, but --

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: Then who says? Heydrich shakes his head dismissively, annoyed that he’d allowed himself to be drawn into an argument.

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: (weary) Don’t start, Schenke. Schenke glances over at Franke momentarily, intrigued -- leans forward eagerly.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: We pulled back without bumping into anyone else. How do you think we got out of there!? (a pause) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So. Who r@uHENKH ecw’ @i1 these 23. other Yanks? Heydrich remains silent -- and Schenke suddenly becomes a that Baumann is standing in the doorway, listening. Baumann and Schenke glare at each other for a moment -- t Schenke SNIGGERS, shaking his head contemptuously. Baumann stands his ground defiantly.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: Krupp wants you up front Schenke takes a small container from his pocket, shakes a pill into his hand, and tosses it into his mouth. Then he gets to his feet and strolls to the door -- pausi just long enough to glare once more into Baumann’s eyes - pointedly and childishly polishing his Iron Cross with hi cuff -- as if to emphasis that Baumann doesn’t have one. And with that, Schenke exits.

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: (after a moment) Little bastard! Baumann changes the subject.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: We’re going to siege conditions. Krupp wants you to organise a rota, three-hour shifts. Heydrich nods, gets up, and departs without further comme The shocked and injured Kreuzmann meanwhile, who has rema semi-conscious throughout, is slowly coming to his senses Still groggy, he struggles to focus on Franke and Baumann

dialogues.speaker: KREUZMANN
dialogues.text: (after a moment) Did ... Engels make it?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: (gently) No. He’s momentarily confused -- then anguish creases his fac as if the memories of what had happened suddenly flood ba FRANKE (cont’d) It’s alright. wWe’re safe, now. Baumann watches as tears drip silently from Kreuzmann’s e Uncomfortable, he, too, departs.  24. Left alone with Kreuzmann, Franke struggles to find words comfort. FRANKE (cont’d) I... couldn’t have got to him, Kreuzmann. I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: KREUZMANN
dialogues.text: Nobody tried to help him. Not even me. Franke doesn’t know what else to say. Instead, he slumps back and blows out a weary sigh. Kreuzmann composes himself slightly after a few moments. KREUZMANN (cont’d) Where is this place?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: (a shrug) Just an anti-tank bunker Kreuzmann shivers momentarily, suddenly chilled. He glanc around the room, as if sensing something...

dialogues.speaker: KREUZMANN
dialogues.text: It’s not safe here. But Franke is no longer listening; he’s studying the fres bullet-dent on the side of his steel helmet introspective as if dwelling on the close-shave. So Kreuzmann turns his attention again to his surrounding his gaze finally settling on the square steel hatch leadi to the bunker’s Emergency Escape shaft...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darkness, except for the faint diffused moonlight filteri in through the loophole at which Schenke is keeping watch Mirus and Neumann are manning the cannon, while Baumann, Ebert and Heydrich wait expectantly just inside the doorw Krupp, meanwhile, is on the field telephone:

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: but the situation’s approaching critical. -- No, we don’t know that for sure. -- Yes. -- Yes, alright He puts down the receiver, exasperated, and turns to the group.  25. KRUPP (cont’d) All units are up at the front. No reinforcements available. We’re to hold until relieved.

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: Hold with what?

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: I doubt they’1l attack the bunker. They don’t know we’re low on ammo, and this time they don’t have the element of surprise.

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: They don’t need it if there’s an armoured column heading straight for us. Krupp glares at him, flustered and annoyed. There are clearly still tensions between the two surviving halves o the group.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: And where’s this armoured column coming from?

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: The same place they did! We don't know what's going on at the front line.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: Command think it’s either an infiltration unit or an isolated pocket of resistance.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: And what do you think about that Baumann? Baumann ignores the mocking tone of Schenke’s voice.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: I think there’s a lot more out there than we realise.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: Well, that’s your story, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: Leave it, Schenke. You don’t know what you’re talking abou --

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: Don’t make excuses for me. Not to him!  26. There’s a second of icy tension -- then Ebert picks up wh the conversation left off.

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: Either way, they must’ve spotted we’ve no covering fire across the pass. And now that it’s dark there’s nothing to stop them surrounding the bunker.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: So what? They won't get in -- nless one of you plans on opening he door for them. ac

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: (to Krupp) bert’s right. And despite having uperman here on our side... (a gesture at Schenke) without ammo, we can't stop them. om

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: And I say they won't attack.

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: Why? Because it's Christmas Eve?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Krupp opens his mouth to argue, but Heydrich interrupts:

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: Lieutenant, you saw the way they came after us. They’re not just doing their job - they're trying to be heroes. He holds out his sleeve, indicating the black, silver- lettered divisional insignia which they all wear HEYDRICH (cont'd) And if they do get in, they won’t be taking any prisoners. There is a moment of reflective silence which temporarily humbles the group. Finally, Ebert again raises his origin point.

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: So. With the bunker surrounded, what options do we have when the ammo runs out? Neumann glances at Mirus, expecting him to say something, the old man is keeping quiet. He then looks at Schenke, a summons up the courage to speak himself:  27.

dialogues.speaker: NEUMANN
dialogues.text: There's always the tunnels. Everybody looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ebert DRAGS open the bolts of a steel door. Schenke, Heydrich, Krupp, Neumann and Mirus are crowded behind him, on the short flight of steps running down fro the entrance passage which we glimpsed earlier Ebert shoves the door open eagerly and shines his torch i the narrow Access Tunnel beyond: about ten metres long; concrete walls; another steel door at the other end.

dialogues.speaker: NEUMANN
dialogues.text: There. Through that other door

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: And what's in there? Neumann shrugs and glances at Mirus, who answers reluctan

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: Only rats.

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: Jesus, don't tell Kreuzmann.

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: (to Mirus) I meant, what are they for?

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: Munitions storage, I think. But they were never finished.

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: (a shrug) I don’t know. Too many cave-ins maybe. They're not safe.

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: But you've been in. Mirus is curiously uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: Not very far.  28.

dialogues.speaker: NEUMANN
dialogues.text: They must go right under the woods. There's a main entrance at the other side of the hill. I've seen it from the outside.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: Were they ever used? Could there still be ammunition stored in there?

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: I haven't been in that far. TI told you, it’s not safe.

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: Why don't we take a look? Ebert starts in, his curiosity clearly aroused -- but Kru calls him back impatiently.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: But if there’s the possibility of --

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: (interrupting) We were told to stay put. Unless something happens, we'll do as we're ordered. (to Mirus and Schenke) And you're both still on watch, in case you’d forgotten. Krupp shoos Mirus and Schenke back towards the Gun Room a follows after them, calling out to Ebert as he goes: KRUPP (cont’d) And make sure that door’s closed! Ebert waits until Krupp has gone, then whispers to Heydri

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: I could just have a quick look.

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: You heard the Lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: Yeah, I heard him. He’s getting jumpy.  29.

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: Well, it’s not every day two-thirds of the unit gets wiped out in one go. (a pause) And look at the group he’s been left with. Ebert ignores the comment with a shrug, pulling closed th Access Tunnel door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baumann is on watch, alone. He's cold, bored, and exhaust He glances out through the loophole momentarily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bunker entrance is visible in the diffuse moonlight. All is quiet. As Ebert had done earlier, he focusses for moment on the name moulded above the steel door.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Moving aside from the loophole, he fishes in his tunic fo cigarette. Lights it with a wind-proof lighter. He then takes out his wallet. Folded inside is a dog-eare PHOTOGRAPH, which he holds in the glow from the lighter: shows a young woman, cradling a cat in her arms. He studies the photo, thinking, and the tough face of the soldier softens for a second. Franke enters and catches sight of the photo before Bauma SNAPS the lighter shut.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: The watch has changed. Go get something to eat. Baumann takes another pull on his cigarette. He's about t stub it out and leave -- but Franke appears as if he want talk, so Baumann offers the butt to him. Franke accepts i awkwardly. FRANKE (cont’d) Thanks. (a pause) So, what about the old man, eh? Jesus! He’s sick; he shouldn't be here in his state.  30.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: None of us should be here. Franke gets to the point

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: Listen... Schenke was out of line, earlier. Always trying to prove something. Baumann says nothing. FRANKE (cont’d) You heard what slipped out the other week? About how he applied to join the SS - and they wouldn't have him!? Baumann nods, a thin smile on his lips.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: I heard.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: He's keyed-up on benzedrine half the time. Getting too fond of it He'll get us all killed, one day. Franke takes a long, deep, nervous pull on the cigarette. FRANKE (cont’d) I tell you; I was scared shitless back there! We've ridden our luck too long, and it's due to run out (he pauses) Half a chance and I would've done the same as you.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: Got out of there while I could. Every man for himself! He takes another pull and offers the cigarette back to Baumann. But Baumann just looks at him curiously -- face blank -- and turns away. Franke frowns, confused -- knowing he said the wrong thin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Krupp, Schenke and Mirus are sitting around the stove, heating soup.  31. As they do so they AD-LIB war anecdotes, the warmth ana coziness -- and in Mirus's case, a bottle of spirits -- having eased the tension slightly. Neumann sits nearby, listening with boyish fascination. Kreuzmann is huddled on a corner bunk, asleep.

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: but he wouldn't listen! So, of course, when he pulled the trigger it blew right back in his face. Took his eye out, and half his cheek with it! (grim chuckle) Served him right, I say.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: Christ! Ebert, meanwhile, slings on his rifle and takes a last gu of his soup before heading for the door to go on watch. Schenke spies this and calls after him. SCHENKE (cont’d) Come on, Ebert. Tell us a quick war story before you go.

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: You’re the hero, Schenke. Not me. He departs, crossing with Baumann in the doorway. Schenke watches as Baumann silently finds an empty bunk.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: (to no one in particular) And not much point asking him, is there. Baumann ignores him. He takes his mug from his kit-bag fills it with soup, and settles back on his bunk to drink Mirus, meanwhile, is offering around the booze once more. Coughing, he pours a shot for himself and Krupp, and hold the bottle out for Schenke.

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: Go on, have one. Look upon it as medicine.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: I told you, I don't drink. (changing subject) So what's your story, anyway? How’d you get the head wound?

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: Got that on the front line, in "seventeen. Shell fragment. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of it Marasidconiin'dpere -- but it doesn't bother me much. Schenke pulls a covert, knowing face at Krupp. Suppressing a smile, Krupp turns to Neumann, who has been listening quietly in the b.g., enthralled.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: You don't say much, do you. Come on, it's your turn. Neumann shuffles, uncomfortable, and unsure what to say. KRUPP (cont’d) Alright, never mind the war stories. How about something funny that happened to you at school? Krupp laughs. Schenke and Mirus join in. Neumann blushes furiously, embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: Ah, leave him. He's alright. Don't worry, kid. Schenke taps his Iron Cross. SCHENKE (cont’d) There's plenty of time to win one of these. This war's not over yet believe me! Neumann looks at Schenke, grateful for the comment. Bauma watching the brief exchange, notices the look of reverenc Neumann's face. However, the atmosphere of anecdotal jollity has stalled and Krupp's attention has been shifted back to the presen Schenke's comment. He's thoughtful for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: So what else do you know about those tunnels, old man? Could we get out that way in an emergency, or not? Mirus is evasive.

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: Maybe... I'm not really sure.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: You know more than you're letting on, don't you. What're you hiding? Mirus shrugs dismissively.  33.

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: Nothing. But Krupp is still waiting, so Mirus finally continues: MIRUS (cont’d) All I know is, there's a whole maze of tunnels and storage chambers. Maybe there’s a way through - maybe not.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: So what happened? Why did they abandon the site?

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: I think there was some kind of revolt by the slave-workers. The 0.T. closed the site temporarily and never came back. Probably the local folk-tales didn't help matters.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: People around here have unpleasant stories about these woods. Ask the kid. He'll tell you.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: You're not talking about ghost stories? Krupp glances around the room, incredulous. Mirus says nothing. KRUPP (cont’d) You're trying to tell me they stopped construction on a military installation because of a few ghost stories? Krupp and Schenke snigger -- but Mirus is serious, his mi seemingly elsewhere.

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: You can laugh here. But in there -- in the dark -- it's easy to believe all sorts of things. Krupp and Schenke’s derisory laughter wakes Kreuzmann, wh emerges from his sleep disorientated. He groggily turns o on his bunk and sits upright. Schenke turns his attention back to Mirus, sneering.  34.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: So just what are these folk-tales? Mirus thinks for a second -- then decides.

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: Alright. I’1l tell you. He shuffles, settling for his story -- taking their scept reaction as a challenge -- and getting that crazy gleam i his eyes once again. He begins: MIRUS (cont’d) You have to remember, these woods are ancient. Older than Germany. People have talked about them for centuries. They used to burn witches here, because the place was supposed to be evil. But it was during the Black Death that the tales really started. Everybody is listening intently. Kreuzmann looks around, puzzled and wondering what he's missed. MIRUS (cont’d) The disease was sweeping across the continent. The village near here was isolated, and they thought they could escape the infection. But there was no escape. The Plague finally took hold and started to spread through the village like wild-fire; and once infected, friends suddenly became enemies. Mirus pauses theatrically, enjoying the reactions of the others as they're drawn in to the story. Kreuzmann is particularly unsettled. MIRUS (cont‘d) Then, at the height of the Plague, a stranger arrived in the village. Some say he was a priest. If he was, then he was a priest of the unholy. Before long, he began to turn the villagers against each other. It didn't take much. He offered to rid the village of the Plague once and for all. And people believed him. Kreuzmann is now white as a ghost. MIRUS (cont’d) One dreadful night, he roused the villagers into a frenzy. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He led a moitRUsi@ontrayp the sick 35. and infected people out of the village, burning their houses one by one. They were pursued into these woods, hunted down like dogs and when they were finally surrounded, they were slaughtered mercilessly. Then their poisoned bodies were buried in the ground. Kreuzmann has listened to enough. Pale and trembling, he shakily gets to his feet and leaves the room. The spell is broken. Everybody shuffles uncomfortably. Mirus looks around. His crazy expression has gone again. MIRUS (cont’d) What's the matter? Schenke glares after Kreuzmann.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it, old man; he's got no stomach, that's all. Been like that for a while. Baumann looks at Schenke silently -- and Schenke returns his gaze with defiant contempt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kreuzmann is leaning over the drain beneath the water tap the corner. Head down, breathing deeply, as if about to b sick. The door of the Gun Room is ajar, and Ebert peers around it to see what’s going on.

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: You alright? Kreuzmann is still groggy and disorientated. He turns on tap and takes a few sips of water from his hand. Then he takes a few unsteady steps along the corridor, clearly uncomfortable with the surroundings.

dialogues.speaker: KREUZMANN
dialogues.text: What’s happening? Are they still out there?

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: All the way around, probably. And this unsettles Kreuzmann even more.

dialogues.speaker: KREUZMANN
dialogues.text: You mean ... we’re surrounded?  36. Ebert realises his mistake.

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: Chances are, they won’t try anything.

dialogues.speaker: KREUZMANN
dialogues.text: But they could get in. If they really wanted to. We all know that.

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: There’s probably not enough of them to try. Kreuzmann ignores him, nervously fingering his cuff insig Kreuzmann,

dialogues.speaker: KREUZMANN
dialogues.text: And you know what they do to elite division troops. As far as they’re concerned, we’re no better than SS.

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: Take it easy. however, won’t be consoled.

dialogues.speaker: KREUZMANN
dialogues.text: There’s something about this place. Something not right. Almost as if we were meant to... He trails off cryptically, then looks at EBERT again. KREUZMANN (cont’d) You haven’t figured it out yet have you.

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: KREUZMANN
dialogues.text: With Engels and the others dead it’s just us again. Just the seven of us. Ebert does seem to know what he’s talking about -- but he changes the subject awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: Better get some more rest while you can. You’re probably still concussed. But Kreuzmann is now staring with moist, emotional eyes a the motto carefully hand painted over the Gun Room door. reads, ‘GOTT MIT UNS’.  37.

dialogues.speaker: KREUZMANN
dialogues.text: ‘God With Us’. (then, to Ebert) But he’s not anymore, is he. We’re on our own. And Ebert doesn’t have an answer. Kreuzmann turns away silently and heads back towards the Crew Room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kreuzmann re-enters the room as discretely as he can. The others are in the process of settling down to get som sleep. Baumann is already huddled on his bunk facing the wall. Schenke, meanwhile, props himself up on his pillow, flicking through an army magazine. And Kreuzmann waits for a moment by the door -- just watching the others pensively, as if seeing them for what they are for the very first time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wind is beginning to gust through the trees, driving th falling snow before it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ebert is crouched with his back to the cannon, idly blowi cigarette smoke into his hands and rubbing them together keep warm. Heydrich is leaning close to the loophole, his eyelids he He breaths in sharply and rubs his face, trying to stay awake. Hearing something, he cocks his head to one side, listeni

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: (a whisper) Come here. Ebert reluctantly gets to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: Listen.  38. They lean closer to the loophole. From the trees, carried on the wind, the faint tune of a distant harmonica; the beautiful hymn SILENT NIGHT. They listen, Heydrich peering outside. HEYDRICH (cont'd) I love the snow. For a fleeting moment, he's MOVED -- then he swallows, pu ing back emotions which are welling up from God knows whe Ebert looks at his wristwatch, struggling to see it in th shaft of dull, diffuse moonlight.

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: Midnight. It’s Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All is still and quiet. All are asleep. Even the hyperactive Schenke, slouched casually on his bunk with h Magazine, is nodding-off involuntarily. Kreuzmann's sleep, however, is troubled. He shuffles in h bunk, unsettled -- as if having a nightmare...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A distorted and surreal sequence -- typical of a dream: Flaming torches, dozens of them, are dancing like fire-fl between the dark, distant trees, accompanied by aggressiv but incoherent SHOUTS. Suddenly, a group of figures BURST into the foreground, a carrying wooden torches and clearly in pursuit of somethi Their dress and appearance is strange -- like people from middle-ages. They carry spears, clubs, and bows. They YELL excitedly, shouting encouragement to unseen comrades -- as if they've just spotted something -- and s up their pursuit. They split up quickly and rush to surround something, bea down upon it with weapons raised, then halting in satisfi anticipation when they have it cornered... Silhouetted in the flickering fire-light -- huddled ina frightened, defensive group -- their quarry is revealed:  39. A small group of men -- wearing the incongruous but distinctive uniforms of German soldiers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kreuzmann awakes with a START. Sweating profusely, taking a second or two to remember wh he is. Then, calming down slightly, he looks around to se if anyone noticed his abrupt awakening. All is just as it was before -- except that Mirus’ bunk i now empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mirus is up to something. He creeps down the short flight of steps to the Access Tu door, torch in hand -- and gently works open the steel bo Easing the door open, he pauses momentarily to ensure he hasn't been heard -- then quietly heads into the tunnel beyond, half-closing the door behind him. But he’s being observed through the crack in the Gas lock door, which is not properly closed... Mirus having moved out of sight, Kreuzmann silently opens Gas Lock door. He, too, listens for a moment to ensure Franke hasn’t heard anything through the heavy steel door the Entrance Defence room. Then, satisfied, he follows after Mirus furtively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FOLLOWING KREUZMANN -- as he creeps along the short dark length of the tunnel, chasing the faint, wavering glow fr Mirus's torch which is visible through the second steel d ajar at the end of the passage. He stops a yard from the door, torch in hand but not swit on. He seems to have a fleeting moment of indecision... Then an indistinct WHISPER draws his attention back towar Mirus. Kreuzmann eases closer to the door, and peers arou  40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mirus is standing about ten yards away, his back to Kreuzmann. He’s silhouetted against the dim glow from his own torch, which is just sufficient to hint at the surroundings: a tall, wide, concrete-lined tunnel which intersects the Access Tunnel at right angles. Now Mirus whispers again, louder, as if calling to someon

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: Martin! I'm here. Come talk to me! He listens for a moment -- then continues forward into th darkness.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Despite his nervousness and confusion, Kreuzmann seems to come to a sudden mental decision: Using a pen-knife, he quickly begins digging and cutting at the stitching of th black cuff-bands on his coat. Finally ripping them loose, he tosses them aside. Then picking at the torn threads which remain in his sleeves, slips through the door and silently goes after Mirus

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ebert shakes Baumann awake as gently and quietly as he ca Baumann turns over in his bunk and looks at Ebert groggil and Ebert quickly holds a finger to his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: (a whisper) Shhh! Don’t wake Krupp. But it’s too late.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: What’s the matter, Ebert? Krupp sits up in his bunk, blinking himself awake. Ebert glances sheepishly at Baumann before answering.

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: I’m not sure. I can’t find Mirus. Or Kreuzmann Krupp glances at his wrist-watch.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: Who's on watch?  41.

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: Me, Heydrich and Franke. But it's time for the shift-change.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: What do you mean you can't find them? Again, Ebert is reluctant to drop his comrade in it:

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: It looks like they're in the tunnels. Krupp stands up, a look of confused incredulity on his fa He moves around the bunks, shaking the others awake, his sleep-befuddled mind still trying to think it through.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: (to Schenke and Neumann) Up. -- Get up! Schenke and Neumann roll out of their bunks. KRUPP (cont’d) Relieve Heydrich in the Gun Room. Schenke rubs his face. He doesn't look as if he slept abo half an hour, and he automatically reaches for the contai of benzedrine pills in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: Do it now, please! Neumann jumps to it. Schenke gets up and follows, glancin sideways at Krupp as he departs. After a moment Krupp turns back to Ebert, picking up the thread of the conversation: KRUPP (cont’d) They're deserting.

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: We don't know that.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: What else do you think they're doing in there? Exploring? They’re looking for a way out.  42.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: If they'd wanted to get out they could've gone through the door.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: If I remember, you were the one who suggested the bunker might be surrounded. The tunnels seem a pretty obvious way out to me. (to Ebert) Whatever the reasons, I want them back.

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: I’1l go.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: Alright. Take Heydrich.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: Heydrich’s injured. I'll go. Baumann stands up, strapping on his pistol belt. BAUMANN (cont’d) Unless, of course, you don't trust me to come back. Krupp returns Baumann's defiant gaze.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: Just don't be too long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baumann and Ebert step from the Access Tunnel, into the w tunnel where Kreuzmann went after Mirus, and they shine t torches in different directions, checking the place out. This place is creepy! Bare concrete walls; curved roof wi lighting fixtures; flat concrete floor with narrow-gauge track running off into the pitch-blackness in either direction; side-tunnels branching off at intervals.

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: God, the air's foul! Nice bit of work, though. Looks safe enough to me.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: Probably not all like this. Their voices echo away in an eerily disembodied fashion.  43.

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: I'll go this way.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: We're not sticking together?

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: Why? You scared of the dark now? He's wearing a teasing half-smile -- which Baumann return

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: Alright. We'll cover more ground, at least.

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: I doubt we'll find them. I found these in the Access Tunnel, before I woke you. He's keeping his voice low, just in case. Pulls out the p of black cuff-bands crudely torn from Kreuzmann’s uniform EBERT (cont’d) Kreuzmann must've dropped them. If Krupp knew about this he'd send Schenke after him -- or inform the Field Police. Or both! Ebert looks Baumann in the eye -- awaiting his response t that last statement. He’s putting his trust in him.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: He won't hear about it from me.

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: Well; if they did find a way out they’1l be long gone. So why don’t we take the opportunity to look around -- just in case we ever need a way out.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: Fine with me. They split up. BAUMANN (cont’d) I'll follow this cable duct. See if I can find a generator.

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: See you back here. Ebert waves a laconic hand in reply as he departs.  44. Baumann, meanwhile, heads in the opposite direction, his torch-beam following the power-cables running along the t of the wall. He's only gone a few paces when his torch-beam begins to weaken and flicker. He gives the torch a shake, and the b brightens again. He looks around to call to his comrade:

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: Ebert...? But there's suddenly no sign of him, and Baumann's voice merely echoes away into the solid darkness. He's alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Krupp is interrogating Neumann. The kid is nervous, and keeps looking to Schenke for support. But Schenke -- keeping watch at the loophole -- is leavin things to Krupp for the moment.

dialogues.speaker: NEUMANN
dialogues.text: I tell you, I don't know!

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: Why is it nobody knows anything around here? (a sigh) The old man's always wandering off into the tunnels, but you don't know why!

dialogues.speaker: NEUMANN
dialogues.text: He's never gone for very long. An hour or so; just to be by himself. He sometimes gets confused. Krupp snorts in mock surprise;

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: Surely not!?

dialogues.speaker: NEUMANN
dialogues.text: But it’s not just his head wound. Or the fact that he’s getting sick. He lost his son earlier this year  45. Schenke glances at Neumann for a second -- then turns his attention back outside. He speaks quietly:

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: We've all lost someone.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: (continuing, to Neumann) Either way, we can assume he’s showing Kreuzmann a way out.

dialogues.speaker: NEUMANN
dialogues.text: (shaking head) I’d ... doubt that, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: NEUMANN
dialogues.text: I'm not sure Mirus would let anyone go with him. He's always told me to stay away from the tunnels. He treats them as if they belong to him.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: Is that why he was trying to frighten us with ghost stories? To try to keep us out?

dialogues.speaker: NEUMANN
dialogues.text: Maybe. He looks to Schenke again, now -- anxious to please. NEUMANN (cont’d) He sometimes acts as if... as if there's something in there he doesn't want anyone to know about. Krupp and Schenke exchange a glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baumann shoves open the heavy steel door and steps inside shining his torch around. He's in a longish room, with concrete partitions separati the heavy utility equipment -- diesel generator; oil burn air-filtration system; all dusty, and slightly cobwebbed. He checks the fuel-gauge on the generator, pulls a face, advances further into the room. Shakes a couple of jerry-cans -- but they're empty.  46. A table near the main electrical junction-box has been le with an assortment of clutter piled high. Baumann unrolls large diagram and studies it. Some kind of plan... A NOISE from somewhere -- unidentifiable. Baumann tenses.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: Ebert? He heads back towards the door, folding the diagram.

dialogues.speaker: SIDE-TUNNEL OUTSIDE GENERATOR ROOM
dialogues.text: Baumann inches through the Generator Room door, securing diagram inside his tunic, and shining his torch in either direction along the narrow side-tunnel. Nothing. He steps out and begins to head along the tunnel... His torch beam flickers again. He pauses and bangs it against the wall. The beam steadies momentarily... then goes out! BAUMANN (cont’d) Shit! ! (louder, now) Ebert! Are you there?

dialogues.speaker: TUNNEL SYSTEM
dialogues.text: Ebert pauses -- as if he heard something behind him -- th shakes his head and continues forward. He studies the walls and roof curiously as he moves froma concrete-lined tunnel-section into an unfinished section. He squeezes past a huge metal rubbish wagon, piled with rubble but abandoned on the track. More clutter is scatte around: Tools; timber; sacks of concrete-mix... MOVEMENT at the extreme limits of his torch-light -- far along the tunnel -- just a glimpse as something disappear around a corner. A figure?

dialogues.speaker: EBERT
dialogues.text: Kreuzmann? Mirus? He heads towards the movement -- stumbling along the rubb strewn floor. Side-tunnels branch off at intervals, and h checks each one quickly as he advances.  47. He CALLS again -- but his ECHO fragments incoherently as bounces away through the complex of tunnels. Now another noise -- a faint SCURRYING sound. He moves towards it, more cautious, beginning to have sec thoughts about being here. He stops and listens; the nois is gradually getting louder. All of a sudden, he doesn't like it! Turns back the way he came. Trying not to rush... but gradually speeding up nevertheless. Turns to look behind as the noise gets even louder. Then back the way he's heading... WHAM! -- as a figure RUSHES out of nowhere, SMASHING into and SLAMMING his head violently back against the wall. He bounces forward and goes down like a ton of bricks! The mysterious figure STUMBLES off blindly into the darkn Ebert weakly lifts his battered head -- his consciousness draining away His torch is lying on its side nearby -- shining along th rough floor -- and illuminating a thousand tiny pairs of which are SCUTTLING towards him. And as he finally begins to black-out As he manages one final, broken, panic-stricken YELL A hundred filthy, scurrying RATS swarm over him ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A circle of torch-light HITS Baumann in the face, and he up a hand to shield his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (urgent whisper ) What the hell is going on? Krupp shifts the light away from Baumann's face as he ste forward from out of the darkness. Heydrich is with him, alert and with rifle ready. Baumann is pale, and trying hard to disguise his relief a being found.  48.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: Torch failed.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: Who yelled?

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: How should I know? I haven't been able to bloody move! Krupp snatches Baumann's torch. Bangs it against the wall Flicks the switch. It comes ON. Baumann isn't impressed: BAUMANN (cont’d) I tell you it wasn't working!

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: Where's Ebert? Baumann is struggling to remain patient. He pulls the diagram from his tunic and tosses it at Krupp.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: Take a look. This place is huge! I don't know where Ebert is; or any of them, for that matter.

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: More to the point -- what happened to make somebody yell out? Krupp is behaving as if he thinks it was Baumann.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: Any ideas about that, Corporal?

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: Yes. Americans. Krupp is wrong-footed. He hadn't even considered it.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: In here?

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: That makes sense. They could've got in from the other side of the hill.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: (annoyed, to both of them) How many bloody Yanks do ou think there are around here..

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: shnn (ater rupting)  49. Heydrich is suddenly alert. Puts a hand over his torch to smother the light. He whispers: HEYDRICH (cont'd) You hear that? The other two catch on instantly -- argument forgotten -- professional soldier taking over as they pull weapons and fall into combat readiness, flattening against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: Which direction?

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: Hard to tell in here. The NOISE comes again. Feet on concrete. Someone's coming All their torches are off. They check both directions alo the tunnel... a GLOW to the left, illuminating the rectangular end of their tunnel. They swing their guns towards it, crouching. Waiting. Silent. Torchlight BURSTS around the corner... Heydrich SHOUTS: HEYDRICH (cont’d)

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: (startled) Who's there?

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: Mirus?? The three soldiers flash on their torches. Sure enough, i Mirus, scared half out of his wits by the surprise. They drop their guns, blowing out their breath in relief. Krupp looks at Baumann with disdain.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: There's your 'Americans'. Mirus joins them, irritation taking over, now.

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: You shouldn't be in here. wWhat’re you doing in here?  50.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: I should be asking that question Private! What's going on? Where's Kreuzmann?

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: I don't know what you're talking about. I was on my way back to the bunker. Why have you been following around after me?

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: We weren't. A pregnant pause... RIFLE SHOT, distant... then the muffled BOOMING of the machine-gun. A split second of realisation...

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: The bunker! then they all RUN LIKE HELL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baumann and Krupp pile inside and RUN along the tunnel, t BOOMING of the guns getting louder all the time. Mirus an Heydrich are slower, trailing several yards behind.

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: Stay here. Watch the tunnels. Mirus remains in the Access Tunnel whilst Heydrich follow Baumann and Krupp up the steps into the bunker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guns are POUNDING again, the air choked with smoke. Neumann swings the big gun from side to side as he FIRES, expression of excitement on his face. Schenke is at the observation loophole, BLASTING off rounds as fast as he c work the rifle bolt. Krupp bursts in; rushes to help at the gun. Baumann, and then Heydrich, go to the loophole to back up Schenke. Schenke finishes his clip. Steps aside to reload. Baumann fills his position. Ready to fire... but he doesn't.  51. He tries to shout over the NOISE of the gun. A nudge from Krupp, and Neumann stops FIRING.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: There's nothing out there. Schenke pushes him aside roughly.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: What's the matter with you? But Schenke freezes in sudden confusion as he looks again outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wind-blown hillside stretches out below, still and empty. No movement apart from the driving snow.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Muffled FIRING continues from the Entrance Defence Room - but from nowhere else. Krupp elbows Schenke aside to look outside for himself.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: What were you shooting at? Schenke and Neumann remain silent, incredulous, whilst Heydrich heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franke is sweating freely -- FIRING through the loophole steady, mechanical rhythm -- almost as if in a trance. Heydrich puts his hand on Franke's shoulder, and he START violently, shaking himself back to reality. Lowers his rifle. He looks around at Heydrich, frightened and confused.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: Jesus, they were everywhere! Trying to get in. I thought for a minute...

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: Easy. They've gone now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Krupp KICKS an empty ammo box against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: Used up! Shooting at shadows! What's the matter with everybody?

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: They were out there!

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: Then why didn't you hit anything? Look outside! Where are the bodies? The others remain silent as Heydrich wanders back in. Kru stands there fuming for a few moments before picking up w he left off: KRUPP (cont’d) I'd expect it from a trigger-happy school kid; but you, Schenke? You should lay off the pills - they're making you see things!

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: Franke saw something too. They can't all be imagining it. Schenke looks at his unexpected ally curiously.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: They're playing tricks on us; hit and run tactics; psychological warfare.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: Keep out of it, Baumann! Krupp turns back to Schenke, exasperated. KRUPP (cont’d) What do we have left?

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: Half a belt for the machine-gun. Whatever rifle rounds and grenades each of us have.

dialogues.speaker: NEUMANN
dialogues.text: There's a few shells for the cannon.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: Against troops!? What good is that, you idiot?  53. Making a decision, he moves purposefully to the field telephone. Picks up the receiver and winds the generator handle. Listens. Winds the handle again. Listens... He's suddenly no longer quite so angry. His voice is shak KRUPP (cont’d) The line's dead!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baumann spreads the diagram he found across the table, an Heydrich leans over to study it

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: It's a site wiring diagram. Not quite a map, but almost as good. Look at the size of the place.

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: Quite a prize for an advancing army. If they could seize it intact.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: Tell it to Krupp. He can't bloody admit he might be wrong. On cue, Krupp and Schenke arrive, still locked in an irritable discussion -- Schenke firmly pushing for action

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: ... It won't be an overhead telephone line, it'll be a ground cable. And if it’s routed back through the tunnels, the implication's obvious! Krupp is more subdued, now; suddenly less sure of himself

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: Alright, suppose the Americans are in the tunnels.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: I say we secure the entire complex, not just the bunker; if they're in there, we push them out.

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: With what, Schenke?  54.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: With our bare bloody hands, if necessary! Heydrich ignores Schenke's challenging glare. Schenke continues trying to persuade Krupp. SCHENKE (cont’d) If they were in there in force, they'd have stormed the bunker by now. It's got to be a manageable number. Krupp is thinking about it all.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: So you think Kreuzmann and Ebert are dead?

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: Deserted, or dead. Either way, we can forget them.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: You're all heart, Schenke. Schenke reacts suddenly and viciously:

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: Shut your mouth, you bloody coward! You had your chance to find them. From what I hear, you preferred to hide away in the dark and do nothing! Heydrich straightens up, shocked at the open accusation, poised to come between Schenke and Baumann... but Baumann takes it without a flinch. He glances briefly at Krupp, then glares into Schenke's eyes:

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: If it’s a scrap you’re looking for, you’11 have to do better than that. (calmly) Get it into your head once and for all, Schenke; I’m not fighting the same war as you.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: (a snort) Isn’t that the truth! Schenke sneers at Baumann's refusal to escalate the confrontation. Grinning triumphantly, he turns his attent back to Krupp, still pressing his case:  55. SCHENKE (cont’d) We can't let them have the tunnels! Krupp agonises for several excruciating moments... then reluctantly nods his acceptance.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: Alright! But if we run into too much opposition we fall back to here. My orders only cover this bunker. But Schenke isn't listening -- he excitedly moves to the diagram spread out on the table, smirking at Baumann.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: This should be interesting!

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHOTS
