dialogues.text: as they prepare for combat Electrical tape stuck across the lenses of the torches, leaving only a slit for the beam. Remaining ammo shared out equally. Equipment strapped on. Guns loaded. Bayonets fixed. Knives and stick-grenades tucked into boots. Schenke surreptitiously pops another benzedrine pill. Sequence culminates with

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Schenke hastily securing a stick-grenade to the insid handle of the main entrance, a web of wire looping back a forth between the door-bolts and the ring-pull fuse. Neumann watches as Schenke finishes the deadly booby-trap

dialogues.speaker: NEUMANN
dialogues.text: Is that to keep them out, or us in?

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: (with a grin) You catch on quick. Neumann licks his lips nervously.  56.

dialogues.speaker: NEUMANN
dialogues.text: Let me come with you into the tunnels. Schenke shakes his head, slinging his rifle over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: No. You're more use here. You did alright back there, on the gun. Neumann starts to protest, but Heydrich, Baumann and Krup appear through the Gas Lock, ready to go. Franke follows, looking at Neumann and gesturing back tow the Entrance Defence Room.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: It's all yours, kid.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: (to Neumann) And keep an eye on the old man! With that, Schenke spins on his heel and leads the others down the steps and into the Access Tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Access Tunnel door swings open. Schenke checks around the corner cautiously before they emerge. Schenke has paired himself off with Krupp, who's now even more subdued, for some reason. When they speak, it's in hushed tones:

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: We'll go straight for the main entrance; you three sweep the long way around. (with mock deference) If that's alright with you, Corporal!?

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: (weary) Give it a rest, Schenke. Baumann turns away without further comment, and the two halves of the group cautiously set off in opposite directions.  57.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN, HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: Franke glances back to make sure Schenke and Krupp are ou earshot.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: I sometimes wonder who's really running this unit.

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: (to Baumann) Why do you let that little bastard keep riling you?

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: What do you want me to do?

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: You could start by telling him what happened back at the ambush. He thinks you chickened out.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: I know what he thinks. And he can believe what he wants to believe. Heydrich shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: Sometimes I think you enjoy being hated! Franke is intrigued:

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: What did happen?

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: We were under fire and he came back to pull me clear after I fell. Risked his neck. So if Schenke asks, tell him.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: Shhh! Baumann gestures for him to be quiet, using the excuse th they're approaching the first corner. Franke looks at Baumann, their earlier misunderstanding clearly on his mi

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: (to Baumann) So ... what you said about all those extra troops

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: If he said he saw them, Franke, he saw them! (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And for al Hav@R@on(cdiheydye in here, now, waiting for us. Baumann pauses by the corner. Flattening against the wall he carefully peers around into the darkness, then checks his torch before nodding the all-clear. They then look back momentarily along the dark length of tunnel they've just covered:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the black distance, the pin-pricks of light from Schen and Krupp's torches wink out as they turn an invisible bend.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: The three of them are now on their own. Baumann consults hastily copied map.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: From now on we'll have to be careful. The leg alright?

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: For the moment. But let me set the pace, will you. I can’t go too fast.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: After you. They set off again into the next length of tunnel. Heydrich slightly ahead on one side, Baumann and Franke o the other side. All of them hug the wall, gun in one hand, torch in the o -- the masked beams of the torches allowing only sufficie light to see where they're treading -- held away from the bodies in case someone takes a pot-shot at the light They're alert to the slightest sound; the faintest trace torch-light ahead. Ready, if necessary, to fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neumann is concerned.  59. The wind is now blowing fiercely outside, blasting flecks snow through the narrow loophole at which he's positioned He's doing his best to keep watch, but his eyes are water against the powerful, freezing draft. Mirus enters the room behind him, and Neumann becomes eve more agitated.

dialogues.speaker: NEUMANN
dialogues.text: Why aren't you watching the front? But Mirus no longer seems to care. He appears worn out, a is now coughing badly.

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: What's the point? We can't see anything out there.

dialogues.speaker: NEUMANN
dialogues.text: Mirus, they left us in charge at this end! We have a responsibility.

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: (angry) Look, they're the ones who brought all this down on top of us. We were doing fine until they turned up! His sudden anger precipitates another coughing fit. He le back against the wall to recover. MIRUS (cont’d) If the Americans attack, let the others deal with it. I've done enough. Dammit, I did my bit twenty-five years ago! Neumann suddenly starts to panic, the responsibility for everything suddenly dumped on his shoulders. He thinks fa trying to reason with the old man.

dialogues.speaker: NEUMANN
dialogues.text: Look, you can't just give up now. We have to do what we can, and at least warn the others of an attack.

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: The danger isn't even out there. It's in those tunnels.

dialogues.speaker: NEUMANN
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? Mirus looks at Neumann defiantly.  60.

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: Martin told me. Neumann can't hide his exasperation.

dialogues.speaker: NEUMANN
dialogues.text: Your son's dead, Mirus. He died at Normandy. You told me so yourself.

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: Don't look at me like that! I tell you he talks to me.

dialogues.speaker: NEUMANN
dialogues.text: You're confused again, don't you see? Martin is dead!

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: They just think I'm a crazy old man. You all do! But there's something about those tunnels. In there, Martin comes back to me. Neumann is just listening, now -- something about Mirus's conviction which unsettles him. MIRUS (cont‘d) Why do you think I've been going in there for the past three weeks? I go to see him. The tunnels are like a doorway, for the dead to come back. Neumann can’t quite believe what he’s hearing -- but Miru continues. MIRUS (cont‘d) Martin told me to be careful; never to let anyone else in. Tonight I found out why. Tonight, when he came back ... others came back with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schenke and Krupp are proceeding in the same cautious fas as the other three: Schenke leads the way like a prowling panther, visibly itching for a scrap, and checking every side-tunnel and chamber with alert anticipation.  61. Krupp, however, is increasingly unnerved, looking around anxiously at the confined space and trying hard not to be a clear case of claustrophobia, which is growing as they progress deeper into the tunnels. They enter an unfinished section of tunnel, water drippin from the roof. After a few yards Krupp pauses to study the map, leaning against the shored wall as he again loosens his collar... A CREAK -- and a stream of earth spills from the roof.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: Christ...! They freeze, coiled -- until the stream abates. SCHENKE (cont’d) Don't touch a thing. This place is a death-trap! And this hasn't done anything for Krupp's nerves! A deep breath, and off they go again. Along... Through into another fully finished section. Whitewashed walls, now. A steel doorway ahead and to the right, with stencilled lettering overhead: MUN-R. They take up position either side of the door. Schenke reaches for the handle. He pushes the door open and follows it inside quickly, shining his torch around.

dialogues.speaker: MUNITIONS STORAGE ROOM
dialogues.text: Krupp is right behind him -- and he stops in amazement, h anxiety momentarily forgotten at the sight before him: A fully stocked ammunition store, abandoned and forgotten Row upon row of wooden racks, stacked with cannon shells boxes of assorted calibres. More boxes -- grenades, and rifle and machine gun rounds -- piled in the corners. Eno ammo to defend a bunker for six months -- gathering dust! Schenke begins to chuckle like an excited child. SCHENKE (cont’d) I don’t believe it!  62. He’s like a kid in a sweet store; he doesn't know where t start! Finally, he crouches over a box of rifle ammo and begins prise it open with his bayonet. SCHENKE (cont’d) Come on, help me! Now we can fight back properly. Now there's no excuse! But Krupp doesn’t quite seem to share his enthusiasm.

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH, BAUMANN
dialogues.text: arrive at a junction of several tunnels. They carefully check each direction.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: We need to go left here, but the other tunnels to the right will still have to be checked out. Heydrich massages his thigh gingerly, wincing in pain.

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: Started bleeding again.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: Look; you stay here. We'll check the other tunnels quickly, then we can move on. Heydrich thinks about it for a second, but shakes his hea

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: That's stupid. We should all stick -- Faint NOISE from up ahead and they're instantly alert, ha covering their torches. Baumann silently dodges across the intersection and begin creep forward, hugging the wall, crouching with rifle poi towards the sound. Heydrich and Franke fall in at the other side of the tunn SCUTTLING NOISE again... Baumann SNAPS on his torch, rifle pointed -- and a pair o rats SKITTER off into the blackness, SQUEAKING. The soldiers blow out their cheeks in relief, uncoiling  63. SUDDENLY -- A human shape BURSTS from a side-tunnel ahead CHARGES away around a corner -- German uniform -- torch waving wildly in its hand.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: (startled) Christ!!

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: Get him! We're behind you! Baumann races after the fleeing figure. Heydrich and Franke follow a few yards behind, covering Baumann's back. Baumann reaches the corner. Quick look -- just in time to see the figure dodging arou the next corner. Baumann runs the length of the tunnel. The other two stil behind. Reaches the next junction: Another unfinished tunnel. Several yards to the left, a s tunnel branches off -- a broken wooden barricade across t mouth -- recognisable as the same location we saw during prologue. Broken as if something had smashed it aside from within. And from inside, the brief shifting GLOW of a torch -- wh then goes out. Baumann gestures to Heydrich that the fleeing figure is i the side-tunnel, and whispers urgently:

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: That barricade is there for a reason. It could lead to a way out! Heydrich nods encouragement. Baumann dodges quickly to the far side of the partly- barricaded tunnel mouth. Heydrich takes position on the n side. Franke hangs back, covering them both. They wait -- listening. Nothing. Baumann points his torch into the side-tunnel, keeping hi head out of the way, and flicks on the beam. Nothing happens. No shots aimed at the torch.  64. So he peeks around the corner to have a look:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crudely shored, claustrophobic tunnel which runs for several yards before curving off into the blackness. A huge amount of clutter and junk and wooden beams, casting large black pools of shadow. But no sign of anyone.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Baumann straightens up. Makes a decision. Nods to Heydrich. Sweeps quickly around into the tunnel mouth... CONTINUOUS SCREAM as someone CHARGES out of the blackness SMASHING into Baumann and bulldozing him back out of the tunnel and into the far wall, KNOCKING the wind out of hi Baumann's torch clatters to the floor and the subsequent STRUGGLE becomes a crazy pattern of shifting black shapes the weak yellow glow. The blind, hand-to-hand combat whic follows is rapid and deadly! Heydrich leaps to Baumann's assistance. BAUMANN (cont’d) (at Heydrich) Wait! It's Kreuzmann! Heydrich hesitates at the revelation... ... but the demented Kreuzmann seems not to hear, turns a CLUBS Heydrich mercilessly with a length of timber. Heydrich goes down -- out cold. Franke leaps on Kreuzmann's back, grabbing the arm which holds the club. Baumann goes for the legs, but Kreuzmann is ready, spinni around and KICKING out viciously... then PUSHING backwards violently so Franke is SLAMMED against the wall and shaken loose. Baumann is into the fray again instantly, BARGING into Kreuzmann and knocking him to the ground, jumping on top him and SHOUTING: BAUMANN (cont’d) Kreuzmann! It's us!  65. He still doesn’t hear. He SCRAMBLES free and runs for it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: What's the matter with him? Baumann grabs his torch and RACES after him, Franke right behind. They run him to ground within seconds, GRABBING him from either side and PINNING him against the wall as he YELLS incoherently. FRANKE (cont’d) Jesus, Kreuzmann, get a hold on yourself!

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: Kreuzmann! Listen to me! Kreuzmann screws his eyes shut, panting furiously. When h opens them again he's calmed down slightly, his struggles easing. BAUMANN (cont’d) It's us. You're alright, now. Recognition slowly seeps into Kreuzmann's eyes... and he suddenly breaks down, sobbing. Franke looks at Baumann.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: Something scared the living hell out of him; and it wasn't us!

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: have left the Munitions Room and are creeping cautiously along a tunnel wall. Schenke is now armed to the teeth -- pockets and belt bulging with ammo and grenades -- and hi desire for a confrontation has increased exponentially.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: I tell you I heard something.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: If the others had run into trouble there would've been shooting.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: I wouldn't count on it, knowing that lot. They were probably yelling surrender.  66. Schenke continues quickly to the next corner, listens for second to the silence, then peers around with the torch. To the right, a wide main tunnel runs off into blackness. the left, the same tunnel runs up a shallow slope to the steel doors of the main tunnel entrance. SCHENKE (cont’d) Cover me. He's gone even before Krupp can get into position. In a running crouch, Schenke dashes up the ramp to the st doors, and shines his torch over them. The huge bolts are padlocked and rusted into place. A smaller man-size doorway, set into one side of the big do is locked and sealed. A mesh of fine cobwebs cover the lo He pushes against the doors with all his weight. They don shift a millimetre. Puts his ear to the doors and listens... Just audible above the gusting wind, the faint sound of footsteps CRUMPING through snow. Then, incoherent whisper Schenke pulls away and dashes back to Krupp, perplexed. SCHENKE (cont’d) The doors are sealed. Nobody got in this way. But there’s definitely someone out there. Krupp wipes his face, relieved.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: As long as they're not in here. He shines his torch around the higher, arched roof of the main tunnel, clearly more comfortable with the extra spac and relaxing slightly. But Schenke remains alert.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: There must be another way in we don't know about -- a vent; escape shaft; something! Schenke moves off along the main tunnel without waiting f reply. Krupp falls in behind, reluctantly, as Schenke continues his rapid left-right check of the side-tunnels chambers branching off either side.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: What about the others? We should wait here, where we agreed!  67.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: We don't even know if they’re still coming. Krupp is losing his patience.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: I still haven't seen anything to suggest anybody's in here apart from ourselves! But Schenke is not listening -- frozen suddenly, and peer around the corner of an unfinished side-tunnel. He glance around at Krupp, gesturing with his head for Krupp to tak look at his discovery. Krupp moves curiously to the corner, and Schenke illumina with his torch beam --

dialogues.speaker: EBERT'S BODY
dialogues.text: Spread-eagled horribly on the floor. Only just recognisable. Covered in rats -- and half-eaten.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: as Krupp turns away, covering his mouth and retching. Sch almost appears pleased.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: Satisfied? Schenke heads into the side-tunnel, kicking at the rats a they SKITTER away into the blackness. Then he kneels beside Ebert’s body. Reaching out to look the wound at the side of his head... SCHENKE (cont’d) Looks like somebody -- A sudden SPASM and Ebert’s body CONVULSES. Schenke and Krupp JUMP, cursing. SCHENKE (cont’d) Christ! (a pause, then) Just a muscle spasm. He’s dead.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN'S GROUP
dialogues.text: Kreuzmann is slumped against the tunnel wall, frozen rigi with fear -- his entire body trembling.  68. Baumann crouches over him, trying his best to sooth his nerves. But Kreuzmann's in no shape to hold a conversatio he keeps drifting off into a world of his own, ranting.

dialogues.speaker: KREUZMANN
dialogues.text: : got confused. Lost Mirus. Then the others started following me. Whispering to me!

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: It's alright. I was left here in the dark. I know what it's like; the pitch blackness, the distorted sounds. I was frightened, too.

dialogues.speaker: KREUZMANN
dialogues.text: They’re in here. They’ve come back for us! Meanwhile, Franke has been tending to the unconscious Heydrich, where he fell several yards away. He gestures n at Baumann, and Baumann leaves Kreuzmann momentarily to j him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: Heydrich's had a bad blow. Give me a hand, will you? Baumann supports Heydrich's head while Franke gets to wor with a field dressing -- glancing at Kreuzmann anxiously.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: (gesturing at Kreuzmann) He's finally cracked. I don't think he even knows where he is.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: Could be delayed shell-shock. Maybe he clobbered Ebert the same way he did Heydrich. They both glance over at him.

dialogues.speaker: KREUZMANN
dialogues.text: is listening to their distant, incoherent WHISPERS... but is staring beyond his present location... elsewhere...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another place, another time.  69. A desolate stretch of bombed-out railway marshalling yard dotted with rubble and ruined sheds and disused rolling stock. A small, agitated crowd of German soldiers. Confusion. Kreuzmann, terrified, is being FROGMARCHED towards the ot soldiers by two black-uniformed SS GUARDS. Somewhere in the b.g., someone is WHISPERING a prayer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heydrich MOANS, delirious.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: It’s no good. We need to get him back to the bunker. (gesturing at Kreuzmann) Both of them. Baumann looks dubious.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: Easier said than done. Let's see if Kreuzmann can walk himself back. They leave Heydrich momentarily, heading the short distan back along the tunnel to where Kreuzmann is still crouche Taking one arm each, they lift him to his feet. Kreuzmann isn't too sure about it, looking blankly from one to the other. Then they try to walk him back towards where Heydr is slumped -- back towards the barricaded side-tunnel...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Kreuzmann experiences another flashback. Still being f marched by the SS guards...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kreuzmann resists, pushing backwards with his feet. Bauma and Franke try to force him, and he starts becoming upset

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: Easy! We're going to get Heydrich, then we're going back to the bunker. You can rest there. They try again, taking Kreuzmann's weight and pulling him forward. His eyes focus on the side-tunnel ahead...

dialogues.speaker: KREUZMANN
dialogues.text: No! He suddenly goes MAD! BREAKS from their grasp, violently. Turns and RUNS.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: God, not again! Baumann and Franke try to catch him, but he's too fast. Disappears around a corner.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: Let him go. We can't leave Heydrich.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: He's scared out of his mind. Maybe something did happen down here.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: Maybe we’d better check that tunnel while we’re here. That seemed to be what was spooking him. They check Heydrich again quickly, then turn their attent to the barricaded side-tunnel. They step through the broken barricade cautiously. Advance along the tunnel. Checking each black pool of shadow, cast by the clutter a around. A SQUEAKING NOISE now becoming apparent as they follow th curve around to the left. Franke shines his torch down suddenly upon a carpet of ra ahead.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: If there's rats in here, there's got to be something else. Then their torches begin to flicker simultaneously.  71. They freeze, worried. Shaking their torches to get them working properly -- but they continue to flicker intermittently. Baumann and Franke exchange a glance then gingerly press being careful not to startle the rats, which retreat slow from the advancing light. The walls here are bare, not even shored with wood -- car out of the earth and left abandoned even before being strengthened... : and suddenly Franke CRIES OUT involuntarily as his torc illuminates a wall ahead. Baumann, too, shifts his torch beam up from the floor -- reacts similarly, recoiling in dread.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: God Almighty! HUMAN CORPSES -- dozens of them. Ancient; half-rotted and half-mummified. Suspended from floor to ceiling in the ba earth of the excavated, crumbling wall. And wherever they can reach, the army of rats are feeding the desiccated remains. Baumann retches and backs away, hugging the tunnel wall. BAUMANN (cont’d) Mirus's story. The Plague victims! Franke covers his mouth -- a hideous realisation dawning his face.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: Oh, Christ, that's it. Mirus!

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: That could be what's wrong with Mirus. Don’t you see; he's got the Plague! They shudder in horror simultaneously and involuntarily. Baumann pulls out his handkerchief and covers his nose an mouth defensively. FRANKE (CONT'D) (cont'd) That's no good! You get it from flea bites! Rat fleas!  72.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: That's it; fuck this place. We're getting out. But before they can even move, something begins to happen As if triggered by their own voices, a faint WHISPERING begins to emanate from all around them. Multiple VOICES overlapping. Unclear at first -- but as it becomes louder, odd phrases stand out. It is a WHISPERED PRAYER -- but far from comforting, in t context -- quite the opposite. Coming from nowhere -- and everywhere -- with no explanation. Baumann and Franke -- both terrified -- don't need to say another word. They turn and RUN instinctively -- back around to where Heydrich is lying. DRAG him to his feet... and get the hell OUT of there!

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: are also at the receiving end of the GHOSTLY WHISPERINGS. They're quickly backing away up the tunnel towards the ma entrance, guns aimed and ready -- backing away from the WHISPERING sounds emanating from the darkness. Krupp is now really edgy -- and beginning to hyperventila Schenke is frustrated at not being able to spot a visible enemy.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: They're playing games with us! Now do you believe me!? Krupp most certainly does. And as they near the main entrance, another disturbance m them SPIN around, even MORE alarmed... a sudden RATTLING of the huge steel doors, as if someone is trying to get in. SCHENKE (cont’d) They're everywhere! Back to the ammo dump.  73. A flat-out RUN back to the Munitions Room, the ghostly VO following behind them. Schenke turns to stand and fight. But Krupp keeps going, back towards the bunker. SCHENKE (cont’d) What're you doing?

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: We're pulling back! I told you before!

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: That was before we found the ammo. We can't leave it for them.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: It's too late, dammit! We can't hold them off. Come on! Krupp continues back, into the dangerous unfinished secti they passed through on the way. Schenke is still arguing he chases after him:

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: We've got a responsibility here. Let's stand and fight! But Krupp shakes his head, no longer even trying to hide fear. Schenke stops, determined to go no further. SCHENKE (cont’d) Then I'll do it alone.

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: You'll do as you're bloody told, for once! Now come on! Schenke ignores him and turns back towards the Munitions Room... and suddenly the WHISPERINGS are SHATTERINGLY LOUD -- seeming to press down upon them. And even Schenke COWERS involuntarily before it.

dialogues.speaker: FOLLOWING KREUZMANN
dialogues.text: as he races blindly through the tunnels, BOUNCING off the walls and around the corners. Enveloped by the overpowering WHISPERS, and out of his mind once again wit fear. Uncontrollably YELLING.  74. Around another corner... and there's a light ahead. Straight towards it at full pelt, still WAILING crazily..

dialogues.speaker: KRUPP
dialogues.text: turn in panic to face this new 'menace' as it races towar them from out of the darkness -- a loud YELL getting LOUD -- louder now than even the other NOISES. Krupp crouches with his gun aimed. KRUPP (cont’d) Who goes there? Stop! -- Stop!! But it keeps coming. Closer... LOUDER... Krupp OPENS FIRE. Schenke joins in. FIRING repeatedly towards the approaching figure.

dialogues.speaker: KREUZMANN
dialogues.text: is stopped dead in his tracks. Jerking like a puppet as bullets RIP into him. Still being riddled even as he goes down.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: continue FIRING, unaware, caught up in the frenzy of the moment. But the POUNDING SHOCKWAVE of the gunfire is too much for fragile roof. A roof-beam shifts; earth begins to pour do Schenke SHOUTS and scrambles backwards... ... but Krupp is too slow. A loud CRACK -- and the entire roof CRASHES down on top of him.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN, FRANKE
dialogues.text: have stopped where they are, listening to the dying ECHOE the distant gunfire. And then the sudden, oppressive SILENCE.  75. Baumann and Franke peer around, frightened and unsure. Bu slowly getting a grip on themselves again, now the terrif ghostly sounds have abated.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: This is insane! This can't be happening!

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: Maybe the old man was right about this place. Heydrich, meanwhile -- still supported between them -- is drifting in and out of consciousness.

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: (confused) What is it? Are they attacking?

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: We don't know what the hell is going on.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: (to Baumann) What do we do? Baumann looks at Heydrich, his mind racing as he weighs u fear against duty, friendship against responsibility.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: God knows. One thing at a time! They hoist Heydrich upright again, and with a fearful gla behind, push on as quickly as they can.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: is frozen against the wall, panting with the adrenalin ru and staring at the nearby cave-in as the clouds of dust begin to clear. Krupp's feet are sticking out from underneath the huge pi of rubble -- twitching violently and accompanied by an al inaudible, smothered SCREAMING. Schenke does nothing. Remains coldly immobile until the screaming dies and the lay still -- if anything, annoyed that the faint noise mi have attracted attention. He continues listening to the silence for a few moments. Satisfied, he lowers himself into a combat-crouch.  76. Glides forward to the wall of rubble which almost -- but quite -- blocks off the width of the tunnel. Listens again -- then shines his torch through towards th bullet-riddled shape lying motionless fifteen yards away. Silently climbs through the jagged gap and creeps forward Reaches the body, rolls it over and studies the face. Kreuzmann! For a moment, Schenke is curiously unmoved by the irony o the situation. Then he laughs. A silent, panting laugh as he covers his mouth and sits b on his haunches. Laughing until tears begin to drip from eyes -- and it's no longer clear if he's laughing or cryi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neumann has made his mind up. He marches through towards Access Tunnel, torch in hand, Mirus trotting along behind

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: Don't be a fool! Whatever the shooting was, it's over. You can't help them. Neumann pauses at the bottom of the steps and glances at Mirus with a curious expression -- a mixture of fear and distaste. Then he heads quickly into the Access Tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again, Mirus follows along behind.

dialogues.speaker: MIRUS
dialogues.text: What are you trying to do; impress them? why don't you ever listen to me, you little idiot. -- Neumann!? But Neumann breaks into a trot -- not wanting to listen - and vanishes around the corner into the tunnel complex. Without his torch, Mirus can't follow. He's suddenly alone.  77. MIRUS (cont’d) Alright, then! Get yourself killed! For what? After a moment he turns back towards the bunker. But some thing makes him hesitate -- draws his attention back towa the blackness of the tunnels. He leans forward, peering.. Is that a shape in the darkness...? MIRUS (cont‘d) Martin? His face twitches into a half-smile... and he begins to hold a conversation with someone unseen. MIRUS (cont’d) Martin, what's happening? I did as you said; I kept away! (a pause as he listens) I couldn't stop the others; they wouldn't listen to me. Tell me what's going on. He listens again -- and the smile drops from his face. MIRUS (cont‘d) Oh, my God! He begins slowly retreating to the bunker -- still listen to 'Martin's' silent instructions -- his unease growing. MIRUS (cont‘d) Oh, God! -- Yes. -- Yes, alright! I'm going! He reaches the door and hesitates just for a moment... only to hear the faint sound of multiple FOOTSTEPS approaching from the tunnels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mirus jumps through the doorway and SLAMS the heavy steel door closed behind him, locking the bolts. He races quickly up the stairs, turns for the door -- and realises the booby-trap grenade is still wired to the han Someone begins HAMMERING on the Access Tunnel door. Without further hesitation, Mirus runs for the --  78.

dialogues.speaker: CREW ROOM
dialogues.text: and straight for the Emergency Escape. Pulls the steel hatch open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baumann BANGS again on the door to the bunker.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: Mirus! Neumann! For God's sake, it's us! He turns an expression of ghastly exasperation at Franke Heydrich behind him. BAUMANN (cont’d) I don't believe it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mirus drags himself through the short crawl-way and into narrow concrete chute which leads straight up to the roof the bunker, four metres above. As he starts climbing the iron ladder, the wind HOWLS overhead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mirus pushes aside the snow-covered camouflage-netting wh covers the top of the chute. Cautiously pokes his head ab the surface, squinting to see in the driving snowstorm. Holding a white handkerchief of surrender in his hand, he begins to haul himself clear of the chute. Something MOVES behind him. A figure, approaching quickly and silently. Mirus doesn't see until it's TOO LATE, and he's

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grabbed from behind -- a knife at his throat. Neumann's eyes are wide with fear as his assailant hesita then whispers quickly in his ear  79.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: Shhh! Schenke eases his grip around Neumann's mouth, but leaves vicious-looking commando knife prodding into his windpipe SCHENKE (CONT'D) (cont’d) What the hell are you doing in here? Were you looking to get out?

dialogues.speaker: NEUMANN
dialogues.text: No! I heard the shooting. Came to help!

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: What about keeping lookout, you idiot?

dialogues.speaker: NEUMANN
dialogues.text: There's a snowstorm blowing outside. We couldn't see a thing. Couldn't hear a thing. Schenke is still dubious. NEUMANN (cont’d) Mirus is still keeping watch -- but I thought I'd be more help in here! Schenke lets go, and Neumann looks around at him for the first time: Schenke’s face is taut with tension -- his ey containing the first faint gleam of insanity. Schenke quickly checks in both directions -- listening intently to the silence -- then whispers urgently.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: Are you really ready to help? To do whatever's required?

dialogues.speaker: NEUMANN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: Ready to take on the responsibilities of wearing that uniform? Despite his obvious fear, Neumann replies defiantly.

dialogues.speaker: NEUMANN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: Then do as I say. Without question. You understand?  80. Neumann nods, and Schenke quickly continues: SCHENKE (cont’d) They're in here. The Yanks. There can't be many -- but they're playing tricks. Trying to confuse us. Pick us off one by one. Neumann nods again as Schenke hands him a couple of clips his rifle. SCHENKE (cont’d) The Lieutenant's dead; the others can't be trusted; so it's up to us. We give the enemy nothing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heydrich is slowly coming around, taking a sip from Bauma water flask. They're hunched nervously beside the sealed door to the bunker: Franke keeping watch towards the tunnels; Baumann wiping Heydrich's brow with a wet handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: God knows what was happening. Franke had an idea -- that we’ve been hit with some kind of nerve- gas.

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: Jesus!

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: Making us hallucinate. It's the only thing that makes sense.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: It would explain a lot... But there's an edge in Baumann's voice, as if he's not re convinced. Franke, however, is sure:

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: It explains everything! Heydrich sits up a little straighter, squinting painfully his befuddled mind struggles with the situation.

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: And the others?  81.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: Who knows? The shooting stopped pretty quickly, then nothing. Heydrich gestures at the bunker door

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: So what now?

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: They're not answering. I think they heard us coming and assumed we were Yanks. Maybe they're just scared and keeping quiet -- or maybe they’ve already surrendered.

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: In which case there could be platoon of Americans at the other side of this door, listening to us...

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: or heading right for us through the tunnels. Franke wipes his mouth nervously.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: Both, knowing our luck! -- The problem is, if we are lapsing into hallucinations, we can't be sure of anything we see or hear. -- Anything!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neumann is carefully piling cannon shells onto a bed of w and sack-cloth, constructed against the base of a fully-l shell-rack. Schenke trots over, carrying a couple of brok open shell cases.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: Wait a minute... He pours some of the cordite from the shell cases over Neumann's bonfire-type construction, then slowly backs aw towards the door, leaving a cordite trail along the concr floor: SCHENKE (cont’d) Alright. More wood and sacking on top. Quickly!  82.

dialogues.speaker: NEUMANN
dialogues.text: What happens to us when this lot goes up?

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: Don't worry. We won't be around here. We've got other things to take care of. Schenke smiles with secret amusement. But, as if on cue to wipe the smile away, the ghostly noi begin again -- very faint at first -- this time a distant unearthly MUTTERING and SOBBING. Neumann crouches, horrified -- hearing the sounds for the first time -- growing pale as the full reality of the situation dawns upon him. Schenke flattens himself beside the doorway, listening. H perfectly calm as he speaks: SCHENKE (cont’d) They're coming again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franke and Baumann scuttle to the end of the tunnel, peer around into the blackness as the MUTTERING draws nearer.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: Dear God, what now? Heydrich joins them; like Neumann, he too is hearing this the first time. He can't quite believe it.

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: Listen to it! It has to be the Americans, trying to panic us.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: (to Heydrich) So what do we do?

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: Blow that door, if we can. Now!

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: But it'll give away our position.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: (to Heydrich) I'm with you. Let's try it.  . . 83. Baumann pulls a stick grenade from his boot. Gets a nod of readiness from the other two. Unscrews the cap. Pulls the loop of string to pop the fuse... Tosses the grenade the length of the Access Tunnel, dropp it smack at the base of the Bunker door. All three pile out into the main tunnel, taking cover eit side of the Access Tunnel mouth. Three seconds ... four ... five BLANG!! and the sharp, deafening BLAST reverberates away throughout the tunnels -- and even here, the lined concre walls and ceiling seem to creak under the strain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schenke and Neumann listen to the dying ECHOES of the bla

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: That was the booby-trap! They’re coming in from both ends, now. (pointedly, to Neumann) Are you ready? Neumann nods, pale and trembling. Schenke takes out his benzedrine pills, shakes one into Neumann's hand, and tips the remainder -- five or six -- his own mouth. Neumann pulls out a small hip-flask and offers it Schenke And this time, Schenke takes it. Washes down his pills wi a belt of booze. Neumann does the same. Then Schenke crouches with his wind-proof lighter -- touc off the trail of cordite on the floor. As it FIZZES quickly towards the make-shift bonfire, Sche takes a final deep breath, hoisting his rifle. SCHENKE (cont’d) This is it. If it moves, shoot! He leads the way out into the tunnels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baumann's torch bores a path through the thick cloud of s and dust as he quickly feels his way, coughing and chokin along the Access Tunnel.  84. He emerges from the fog to find the bunker door dented -- intact. His face is a picture of despair. He kicks at the door impotently as Heydrich arrives behind him.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: Shit! -- If anything, it's jammed in tighter! Heydrich joins in, kicking at the door as best he can wit his good leg -- but it's useless.

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: You bastards! Open up! He gives up, slumping against the wall as a wave of dizzi overwhelms him momentarily. Baumann stops, too.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: Alright. Alternative plan. Can you run?

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: Not much choice, is there. They reluctantly turn away and scurry back to where Frank guarding the doorway into the tunnels. The ghostly noises are still apparent -- and even closer

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: Dammit, that can't to be real!

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: (to Baumann) So what is this alternative plan?

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: Find Schenke and Krupp? Find the main entrance? Take your pick! The three glance at each other -- but none can think of anything better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as they dodge out of the Access Tunnel doorway and advanc a well-rehearsed manoeuvre -- Franke setting the pace at point, Baumann and Heydrich guarding their rear.

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: This is some fucking Christmas, alright!  85. And following them slowly all the way, the ghostly MUTTERINGS of the unseen pursuer.

dialogues.speaker: MUNITIONS STORAGE ROOM
dialogues.text: The dry sack-cloth bed of the bonfire BURSTS into flames the FIZZING fuse-trail hits it. The flames build quickly through the tangled lattice of w licking at the brass cases of the piled cannon shells...

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN, FRANKE
dialogues.text: Franke gestures for the others to follow as he advances around a corner. Baumann and Heydrich trail after him, still watching the rear... FLASHES from the darkness ahead -- followed immediately b POUNDING GUNFIRE. Bullets CHOP into the walls -- into the floor. They scramble backwards in panic, returning FIRE. Take cover around a corner, still FIRING blindly back tow the unseen sniper -- until their guns CLICK on empty.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: I'm out!

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: Me too. Franke fishes one final five-round magazine from his pock Pushes it into his rifle with a trembling hand.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: Last chance, then. He FIRES once around the corner, then they RUN for it alo the side-tunnel in which they’d taken refuge.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: Schenke, in the shelter of a recessed doorway, lowers his smoking gun and quickly changes magazines -- listening. Neumann, meanwhile, is shaking like a leaf -- for this is first ever taste of running combat. Schenke hisses at him

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: They're getting away! Come on!  86. Neumann follows along blindly as Schenke breaks cover

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN, FRANKE
dialogues.text: They CLATTER along the side-tunnel -- stealth now sacrifi for speed. Franke is pulling ahead, but Baumann, dragging along Heydrich, is unable to keep up. Franke SKIDS to a halt at a junction of cross-tunnels, an checks in each direction: A moment of dreadful, realisation... Far along the tunnels, high-lighted as just the vaguest o flitting, ambiguous shapes -- figures seem to be dodging cover to cover -- in every direction. And the uncanny voi continue menacingly. As Baumann and Heydrich arrive behind him, Franke pulls b his face ashen and fearful.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: Christ, they're everywhere! We don't have a chance! Baumann takes Franke’s place, peering around the corner

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: Where are they? I can't see... But Franke turns to face the direction they’ve just come. FOOTSTEPS are now rapidly approaching along their tunnel. and Franke is moving to meet them.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: This is it. We’ve nothing left to fight with.

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: Franke, wait...!

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: Let's try to reason with them. They can't kill us; it's Christmas day! Baumann's not convinced; he pulls Heydrich around the cor away from the approaching FOOTSTEPS, looking around wildl for other signs of threat -- his bayonet ready... Franke continues forward, tossing his rifle aside and rai his hands:  87. FRANKE (cont’d) Enough! We surrender. Don't shoot! Torchlight BURSTS from the blackness ahead. Franke stops, pinned like a moth in the glare. FRANKE (cont’d) We give up! Do you hear?

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: I hear. Franke is startled by the familiar voice. He drops his hands.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: Schenke! Thank God! Quick, they're all over the place. Baumann and Heydrich, too, are relieved. They quickly ste back around the corner, shielding their eyes against the glare from Schenke’s torch. The dialogue exchange is rapid:

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: Did you find the way out? Where is it? Schenke moves the light away from their eyes -- allowing to see the pistol he's pointing at them -- and the rifle which Neumann also has trained on them.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: Nobody's getting out. Not them. Or us. Baumann can tell instantly from Schenke's expression that something's not right.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: Where'd you get all the ammo, Schenke? What's going on? Who's in the bunker?

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: What's going on is this: Krupp's dead. So are Ebert and Kreuzmann. And lacking a suitable replacement, I've assumed command.

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: Jesus! What happened?  88.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: You three weren't at the rendezvous, that's what happened.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: Now wait a minute...

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: Never where you should be, Baumann! But this is the last time. (to Neumann) Take a look, kid; this is the reason we're losing the war

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: For Christ's sake, Schenke, they're just around the corner! Do something! But Schenke merely straightens his arm, aiming even more deliberately at Franke's face.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: (continuing, to Neumann) The reason we've been pulling back for the last six months! Cowards who won't bloody fight! The tension is suddenly electric. Neumann, too, now sees way things are heading, and begins to shuffle nervously. Franke pleads with Schenke.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: We've had nothing to fight with! Just show us the way out, will you!

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: Don't worry about the Americans. I've taken care of that. But first things first. -- Time to weed out the traitors. Baumann doesn't wait for Schenke to continue. He looks straight into Neumann's eyes and addresses him.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: Don't listen to him. Can't you see? He's half out of his mind!

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: Time to prove yourself, kid! They don't deserve to wear that uniform. Prove that you do. Neumann looks at Schenke.  89.

dialogues.speaker: NEUMANN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: Do I have to spell it out? Neumann looks at the others, wide-eyed -- his rifle still pointed at them.

dialogues.speaker: NEUMANN
dialogues.text: But...

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: (to Neumann) Don't listen to him!

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: They're traitors and cowards! You know the law. Shoot them!

dialogues.speaker: NEUMANN
dialogues.text: I can't... I can't just... But Schenke suddenly GRABS Neumann's hair with his free h and SHAKES his head violently.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: Damn you! That's an order! Do it! Neumann is trembling as he aims his rifle at Baumann and SCREWS his eyes shut -- tensing himself for the shot... Baumann waits for it ...! A terrific BLAST -- RIPPING through the complex as the distant Munitions Room finally, inevitably GOES UP! The walls SHAKE. Schenke, off balance, lets go of Neumann and OPENS FIRE o the others himself. Franke is HIT in the arm as he instinctively CHARGES Sche CRASHING into him and knocking him off his feet. Baumann KNOCKS Neumann's rifle aside and SLAPS him hard across the face, furious! Continues SLAPPING him back and forth. Another deep BLAST shakes the tunnels. Schenke is on his back on the floor, scrabbling for his t and gun. Baumann shouts to the others:

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: This way! Run!  90. Franke and Heydrich help each other. Baumann grabs Neuman by the scruff of the neck and DRAGS him away.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: Not that way! The soldiers ...!

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: I know what I'm doing! Come on! And he leads them straight forward without hesitation, ac the junction and along the next tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: climbs to his feet, watching as the others escape into th darkness. And he begins to emit, incongruously, a growlin MOAN of frustration ... as the distant explosions continue, almost drowning o the ghostly mutterings... : a deep, extended WAILING MOAN -- which slowly builds in pitch and fervour into a long, furious, BELLOW of insane rage!

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN, FRANKE, HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: are suddenly running through a NIGHTMARE! Schenke's distant WAIL echoes around them and seems to initiate an answering GHOSTLY CHORUS of horrific SHOUTS a SCREAMS of anguish. Souls, literally, in torment! The group is on the verge of going to pieces in fear and confusion. They scramble recklessly along, covering their ears against the SCREAMING and POUNDING EXPLOSIONS which threaten to deafen them. But then... BAUMANN (cont’d) There! In there! And the four fugitives race towards a doorway in the tunn wall ahead... and PILE inside.

dialogues.speaker: GENERATOR ROOM
dialogues.text: Baumann bolts the steel door behind them. But there's still no escape -- the blood-chilling NOISES in here with them -- even louder, if anything.  91. They back away and huddle together in a corner, covering their ears and screwing their eyes shut -- quite literall FROZEN with fear -- nowhere else to run. It seemingly can't get any worse, when... The CACOPHONY of noises begins to fade, and one particula voice takes precedence -- a voice WHISPERING a PRAYER... Baumann opens his eyes wide with an expression of horrifi recognition... BAUMANN (cont’d) Oh, Jesus! It is them! The whispering overlaps into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baumann's fragmented visual recollections of a horrific event. The same railway marshalling yard we saw before, but this time from Baumann's perspective. He and other members of the unit -- Heydrich, Franke, Ebe Kreuzmann and Schenke -- are being marched towards an isolated, bombed-out area by Krupp and the two black- uniformed SS guards. Ahead, an SS CAPTAIN waits beside a pit which is being du a large group of prisoners -- themselves uniformed GERMAN SOLDIERS, possibly deserters, stripped of helmets and equipment -- who are working at the gunpoint of a third S GUARD. Some are working with spades, others are forced to scratc the earth with bare hands -- trying not to look at the approaching soldiers, as if to deny their existence. One prisoner is already kneeling, muttering the loud but whispered PRAYER which continues relentlessly... Now, the prisoners become agitated as Krupp's men arrive broken line beside the pit. A couple of the prisoners bre down suddenly, moaning, muttering and sobbing. As Baumann stares down into the trench with appalled anticipation, the faces etching themselves into his memor one prisoner in particular catches his gaze, and stares b with an expression of silent pleading.  92. Kreuzmann has begun trembling violently. He turns away in mounting fear and tries to walk back the way they've come but the SS guards, laughing, trot after him, spin him aro and frog-march him back towards the others. The SS Captain now seems in a hurry to get it over with. passes an order to Krupp, gesturing at the prisoners -- h intention unmistakable... And at this defining moment of truth, each soldier reacts his own way: Krupp turns to his men and reluctantly relays the order Schenke raises his rifle at the cowering prisoners. Kreuzmann, in terrified, trembling submission, follows suit. The others are frozen with indecision... The SS Captain SHOUTS the order again, increasingly angry Franke finally, reluctantly raises his rifle. Ebert and Heydrich remain frozen. Only Baumann actively revolts. He turns on the others, knocking their rifles aside and pushing them back from the pit. Arguing with Krupp and the SS captain... Heydrich now trying to hold him back for his own good... And during the utter confusion, several of the prisoners their last chance. They try to scramble out of the pit. Three or four even make it out. A couple run for it. One rushes at the SS Captain, hands outstretched. The SS Captain SHOUTS a warning... Krupp shoots the would-be assailant. Schenke turns and OPENS FIRE on the rest of the prisoners mercilessly. Ebert, Franke and Kreuzmann fire almost as a reflex, drawn in by the sudden panic. The prisoners are cut down under the hail of bullets. Baumann, still being restrained by Heydrich, watches in HORROR. The GUNFIRE ceases. But several bodies still twitch and moan from the pit The soldiers stare down at what they've done.  93. Schenke coolly changes his rifle magazine, just in case. Kreuzmann, weeping, drops to his knees. The others try vainly to cover up their revulsion. And meanwhile, the three SS men begin to amuse themselves pushing the heaps of excavated earth back into pit with t As the earth spills down onto the pile of bodies, the one still alive begin to SCREAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the same SCREAMS which Baumann, Franke, Heydrich and Neumann are hearing now. Baumann looks at the others -- and with the exception of Neumann, each returns the same expression of horrified recognition. Neumann's expression is simply one of frozen terror. The screams diminish again to a series of quietly mutteri voices -- the very essence of which is frighteningly threatening. Franke is almost losing it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: Kreuzmann was right. They've come back! They're making all this happen! Turning us against each other!

dialogues.speaker: TUNNEL SYSTEM
dialogues.text: As SHUFFLING feet seem to approach from the blackness Schenke turns to confront whoever it is. He appears perfectly -- almost unreasonably -- calm as he addresses the unseen newcomers.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: I'm not afraid of you. I've got a cross to protect me! He holds out his Iron Cross -- and begins to LAUGH...  94.

dialogues.speaker: GENERATOR ROOM
dialogues.text: An INHUMAN POUNDING begins on the steel door.

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: Is it Schenke? It must be Schenke!

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: Whoever it is, they know we're in here. Baumann is looking around in controlled panic. Spies something. BAUMANN (CONT’D) (cont'd) Give me a hand! A metal grille is set into the concrete floor next to the filtration unit. Baumann takes out his bayonet and begins prise the grille free. Franke catches on and kneels to he him with trembling hands. Yet another huge explosion SHAKES the fabric of the tunne system, and cracks begin to appear in the walls. The POUNDING on the door continues, as if a huge hammer w being swung against it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: Quickly! They wrench the grille free, and Baumann briefly leans in the dark horizontal shaft, shining his torch either way.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: Alright! In! Another BANG, and the door shakes on its hinges. Franke g into the shaft like a shot.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: Which way?

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: Either! Just go! (to Neumann) You next!

dialogues.speaker: NEUMANN
dialogues.text: We can't just leave Schenke behind!

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: You still think he's such a hero? Because he wears that medal? Then stay with him!  95. Neumann makes a hasty decision. Clambers into the shaft followed by Heydrich. Another HUGE BANG and the door rattles dangerously. Bauma ducks into the shaft after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tight fit! Solid concrete. No going back. Franke struggles ahead as fast as he can. The others craw along, head to foot behind him, already regretting it. The POUNDING continues behind them.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: I can't see how far it goes. What if it's a dead-end?

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: It has to come out somewhere. Just keep going! A final BANG from back in the Generator Room, and the muf CRASH of the door giving way.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: They're through the door. Everybody shifts up yet another gear, scrabbling along as fast as is possible on elbows and knees. Franke is beginn to panic. His torch reveals a blank wall dead-ahead; a tu

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: Oh, God! A bit closer. Not a turn -- it's a FRANKE (cont’d) Dead end! It's a dead end! A string of frightened, AD-LIB CURSES.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: It can't be. Keep going! Franke scrambles the last few yards -- hoping against hop

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: Oh, God!

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: Up! Look up! Franke shines his torch upwards. An iron grille!  96. The others pile up behind Franke as he tries to push the grille open. No go! And now something's coming slowly up the shaft behind Baumann... BAUMANN (cont’d) They're coming. Get OUT! Franke and Neumann brace their shoulders against the over grille and PUSH. It won't budge! Again

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The grille BURSTS open. Franke and Neumann are out in a flash. Heydrich next -- dragged out. Then Baumann. Half-way out when... his legs are GRABBED from behind. Is it Schenke? He YELLS and KICKS himself free. As the blasts continue -- tearing the tunnels apart behin them -- they run for their lives. And they're not the only ones. The colony of rats, driven mad by the explosions, is running in all directions scratching and tearing at anything in their path. Their numbers increasing as the soldiers continue their reckles flight. CURSING and PLEADING with God for help as they go. They try to go one way -- but the roof is already coming down. Another direction -- but a virtual river of crazed rats i pouring towards them! They can't go back -- only one way remains...  97. Forward, into the unfinished section where they encounter Kreuzmann -- and back to the barricaded side-tunnel! They freeze in panic. Knowing it's a dead-end. Baumann's mind is racing. Searching for a way out. Meanwhile, the walls are crumbling. Rats are scampering wildly all around them. Jumping at their legs and gnawing at their boots. It's a living-hell! And just for good measure, Schenke's insane shouting begi to echo towards them.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: There's no way out, Baumann! And we're coming! For some reason, everybody looks instinctively to Baumann And his expression shows he's suddenly thinking again -- ray of hope on his face as he digs into his tunic pockets

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: What do we have? Turn it all out Everybody begins scrabbling through their pockets and pouches, grasping at any last straw. Pulling things out: Penknives; bandages; compasses; signal flares... Baumann GRABS the flares from Franke, and pulls the foldi entrenching spade from his belt. No time to even explain. BAUMANN (cont ‘d) Come on! And he rushes into the barricaded side-tunnel. Heydrich a Neumann, who don't know what's in there, follow him in -- Franke takes a few steps and stops. Won't go any nearer.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN, HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: rush into the chamber of horrors Baumann had seen before. This time it's worse: The tremors from the distant explos are shaking the earth loose from the walls -- revealing e more bodies -- their mummified limbs moving as if alive. Heydrich and Neumann have a moment to react with predicta shock and fear -- then their torches flicker and die! A moment of blackness, accompanied by fearful SHOUTS.  98. A FLARE shoots out, bounces off the ceiling and into a corner, CRACKLING as it illuminates the chamber with blue flickering light. Baumann doesn't wait another second. Begins dragging sack of concrete mix against the wall containing the corpses piling them up, yelling as he does so. BAUMANN (cont’d) Help me! They can't be buried very deep. We can't be far beneath the surface! Heydrich catches on straight away. Unfolds his entrenchin spade, clambers on top of Baumann's makeshift platform, a begins DIGGING into the roof, corpses inches away from hi face in the wall. Earth begins to shower down. Neumann manages to gather himself sufficiently to take ov from Baumann, dragging more sacks over to build the platf higher. And Baumann joins Heydrich, HACKING furiously up into the roof.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKE
dialogues.text: is hovering indecisively just inside the broken barricade Schenke's voice calls again out again, closer.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Neumann? Where are you? Franke? Franke looks one way, then the other -- trapped between t equally unappealing options. He's hyperventilating. Tryin to keep himself together BASHES himself on his forehead with the palm of his hand. ... and turns decisively to confront Schenke, his bayonet gripped tightly in his fist as he rushes back out through barricade.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN, HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: Only now does Baumann notice Franke isn't with them.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: Where's Franke? He jumps down, tossing his spade to Neumann, and retreats back along the side-tunnel whilst Neumann takes over digg  99. Baumann’s torch is still not working, but he proceeds as back into the gloom as he can, calling out. BAUMANN (cont’d) Franke? -- Franke? There is the SOUND of a violent scuffle from the darkness Then a single SHOT. And Schenke's voice, calling over the continuing RUMBLE o detonations:

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Franke died like a dog, Baumann! And you're next! A sudden ANGER surges through Baumann.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: I'm ready for you, Schenke! Come and get me!

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: have dug a yard upwards into the already shifting, crumbling roof. A huge clump of earth falls away suddenly and the HEAD OF A CORPSE swings down, dangling. Neumann SCREECHES! Heydrich is shaken, but instantly continues digging to one side.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: is stumbling forward, bayonet in hand, towards the approaching glow from Schenke's torch. Suddenly Schenke is there -- framed in the mouth of the s tunnel. And in the blackness behind him -- only hinted at the glow of his torch -- is a suggestion of several ghost figures. Their muttering, ghostly VOICES still unintelligible, but they seem almost to be offering evil encouragement to the crazed instrument of their vengeance -- Schenke! Baumann is shaken to the core by the sight, but holds his ground, trying to convince himself he's seeing things. BAUMANN (cont’d) Put the gun down, Schenke! I'll fight you! That's what you wanted.  100.

dialogues.speaker: SCHENKE
dialogues.text: Wrong! All I want is to see you dead! Schenke raises his pistol, laughing... But Baumann aims quickly and FIRES OFF a signal flare. It flashes like a ROCKET across the distance between them SLAMMING into Schenke's chest -- and engulfing him in FLA Schenke SCREAMS and staggers backwards out of sight, arms flailing -- and once again his screams seem to trigger th HOWLING FURY of the ghostly presence. Baumann gets out of there as fast as he can -- back to wh

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: are digging upwards like maniacs. Four feet into the roof Urged on the by renewed cacophony of terrifying voices. The flare they're using for illumination is fizzling out and in the strobe-like flickering of the light, the faces of the mummified plague victims seem to come alive -- jus for a subliminal split-second at a time -- hinting at the haunting faces of the soldiers shot in the pit... Baumann FIRES the third and last flare into the corner. Then jumps up to help Heydrich and Neumann, tearing at th roof with his bare hands. But something's coming at them again; DRAGGING itself tow them from the darkness... Baumann takes the spade back from Neumann. Kneels on Heydrich's shoulder. Pushes himself higher. Digging... . Six feet upwards. Hacking through roots, now. Earth pouring down around him... An inhuman GROWL from Schenke as he STAGGERS into the cir of flickering light, horribly burned and smouldering... Neumann CRIES OUT! Baumann BURSTS through the roof! Earth and grass and snow spill down as the storm above WHISTLES through the tiny opening. and Schenke CHARGES!  101. Baumann drops down from Heydrich's shoulder as Schenke bulldozes into them, slashing indiscriminately with a kni and now totally insane! Baumann GRAPPLES with Schenke, yelling to the others;

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: Out! Get OUT! Neumann doesn't argue. Scrambles up through the tiny opening, boosted by Heydrich. Schenke TOSSES Baumann aside like a doll, and goes for Heydrich, STABBING at him with one hand whilst PULLING at Neumann's legs with the other. Baumann DRAGS Schenke away. Pushes Neumann upwards so he crawl out. Tries to help the bleeding Heydrich back onto feet... then all hell breaks loose! The wall seems to SHIFT behind them, and mummified corpse SPILL OUT around them, limbs everywhere -- which seem to suddenly GRAB at Baumann and Heydrich. Holding them again the wall! They struggle in HORROR! Schenke is coming for them again. The last flare is fizzling out. The light spluttering and dying... And behind Schenke, seemingly closing in to watch the kil is the line of ghostly figures -- fleeting glimpses of fa and uniforms, strongly suggestive of the prisoner soldier massacred in the pit. Schenke attacks again, and a grisly, three-way wrestling match begins amidst the tangle of clawing, mummified arms Baumann is STABBED once in the shoulder. Fights back furiously, partially breaking free from the grasping arms and trying to twist the knife out of Schenke's grip. Heydrich goes for Schenke’s throat. But Schenke pulls himself from Baumann's grip -- and PLUN the knife into Heydrich's chest. With a final, supreme dying effort, Heydrich grabs Schenk wrists in an iron grip -- and holds the knife into his ow chest, trapping it!

dialogues.speaker: HEYDRICH
dialogues.text: (to Baumann, last breath) Get OUT!  102. Baumann hesitates for a split second -- looking into Heydrich's dying eyes. Schenke is struggling to pull the knife free in order to turn on Baumann, RAGING incoherent Then, in one swift motion, Baumann grabs the last grenade lodged in the top of Schenke's jackboot and CLAWS his way towards the opening above. The rotting arms seeming to PULL at his clothing. Trying to drag him back. Neumann is calling from above:

dialogues.speaker: NEUMANN
dialogues.text: Grab my hand! Behind Baumann, Schenke finally DRAGS the knife free from Heydrich -- who falls over dead. Then Schenke LUNGES after Baumann. Pulling at his legs. Raising the knife to strike... Baumann grabs Neumann's hand. HAULS himself up through the tangle of tree-roots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the freezing storm ROARING around them, Neumann pull Baumann half-way out from the tight, crumbling hole in th ground. Baumann slumps to one side, still KICKING at Schenke's grasping hands, STAMPING him back down. He rips the cap from the grenade. Pops the fuse. Drops it down the hole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The grenade drops at Schenke's feet. He KICKS it away and tries one more time to SCRAMBLE up through the hole. But he’s tangled in the gruesome web of grasping arms. An now the ghostly figures, too, CROWD around, pressing down him... The grenade EXPLODES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baumann and Neumann are already running for it as a huge of snow-covered ground behind them SHUDDERS upwards from subterranean blast, then SINKS back with a dull THUD. The storm continues to blow, piling fresh snow on top of cracked, uneven depression. Slowly covering it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The snow-storm has abated, to be replaced by a slow, sile shower of snowflakes. Baumann and Neumann are huddled together in a shelter car from a snow-drift at the base of a tree, still trembling the horrors of the night as much as from the cold. Baumann sighs wearily, puffing on a cigarette as he approaches the end of a quietly spoken story:

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: some of them were still alive when the pit was filled in. -- Then we were sent back to the barracks as if nothing had happened. All part of the day's work He sits quietly for a few moments, thinking. BAUMANN (cont’d) We told ourselves they were Americans; enemy infiltrators. But they were probably deserters from our own ranks. Better for us that we never knew. -- But in the end, what's the difference? Neumann sits silently, letting the story sink in. Whilst does so, Baumann reaches deep inside his tunic. Pulls out small, flat black box. Neumann watches as he opens it up. Inside is an Iron Cros ist Class. Neumann looks up at Baumann. He opens his mouth to ask something -- but realises he already knows the answer. BAUMANN (cont’d) Some people couldn't understand why I stopped wearing it. Baumann closes the box, PUSHES it deep down into the snow and covers it over.  104. BAUMANN (cont’d) But there won't be much glory for the wearers of those. Nor any mothers proud of their sons for wearing this uniform. If you've any sense you'll save your courage for when this war's over. -- That's when you'll really need it Baumann struggles to his feet with finality, forcing his exhausted, aching body upright. BAUMANN (cont’d) It's light enough, now. He trudges quietly forward towards a snow-covered ridge, carefully and silently crawls up to look over the top. Neumann quietly approaches behind as Baumann peers throug his field glasses.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH BINOCULARS
dialogues.text: The frozen dirt-road and the bunker are visible through t trees in the distance. At the rear of the bunker, several green-uniformed American soldiers are milling around. The unmistakable, grey-uniformed figure of Mirus is with them. An armed guard stands next to him as he tries to converse with an American officer. He's clearly nervous sick and confused -- but, at least, alive.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Baumann pulls back from the lip of the ridge and turns to Neumann. BAUMANN (cont’d) Have you got a handkerchief? Neumann shakes his head. Baumann pulls out his own and gives it to him. BAUMANN (cont’d) Here; wave it. Don't try to hide. Just walk straight down. You'll be alright.

dialogues.speaker: NEUMANN
dialogues.text: But aren’t you coming? After everything you said... Baumann shakes his head.  105.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMANN
dialogues.text: I can't get out of it that easily. I have to stick it out to the end, now. But for you, it's Christmas. You've been given another chance. -- Now get going. Baumann's voice is suddenly harsh, and Neumann reluctantl does as he's told. But after a few steps he pauses.

dialogues.speaker: NEUMANN
dialogues.text: Mirus told me... he told me this was a place where the dead come back (a pause) But we didn't really see anything, did we. It was nerve gas; made us see things; hear things; drove Schenke mad? Baumann doesn't answer, and after a moment Neumann turns again and heads off through the trees, down towards the bunker. Baumann watches Neumann go -- then turns and trudges off the opposite direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The depression in the ground is covered over completely, All that's visible is a smooth, white concave sheet of vi snow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blackness. A muffled GROANING, as if someone has suddenly woken. Then a shuffling panic. A CLICK -- and a cigarette lighter flickers into life... illuminating the tiny pocket of dusty air into which Schenke is crushed under tons of rubble. Only his head an one arm are free in the narrowest of cramped, confined spaces. Burned, battered and torn but, incredibly, still ticking -- for the moment. And, unfortunately for him, a vestige of sanity and comprehension seems to have returne It takes him a second to fully recognise his predicament. Buried alive!  106. And as if that’s not enough... as the horrifying realisation slowly sinks in... : he begins to hear a SCRATCHING sound. As if something i beginning to CLAW its way through the rubble towards him. Getting closer. Rats? Or something else...? Schenke STRUGGLES furiously, but can barely move an inch. Panic setting in. Can’t breathe! The cigarette lighter beginning to sputter and die... The scratching getting LOUDER and CLOSER. until the tiny flame dies and blackness closes in. Then Schenke SCREAMS! im jz jo
